258.03
236.01 ELECTION; TERM; QUALIFICATIONS.
   The Auditor shall be elected for a term of four years, commencing on the
first day of January next after his or her election. He or she shall be an
elector of the City.
236.02 BOOKKEEPING.
   The Auditor shall keep the books of the City and exhibit accurate statements
of all moneys received and expended, of all property owned by the City and the
income derived therefrom, and of all taxes and assessments.
(ORC 733.11; 1978 Code § 32.30)
236.03 AUDITING ACCOUNTS.
   At the end of each fiscal year, or oftener if required by Council, the
Auditor shall audit the accounts of all officers and departments. He or she
shall prescribe the form of accounts and reports to be rendered to his or her
department, and the form and method of keeping accounts by all other
departments and, subject to the powers and duties of the Auditor of State,
shall have the inspection and revision thereof. Upon the death, resignation,
removal or expiration of the term of any officer, the Auditor shall audit the
accounts of the officer and, if the officer is found indebted to the City, the
Auditor shall immediately give notice thereof to Council and to the Law
Director, and the latter shall proceed to collect the indebtedness.
(ORC 733.12)
236.04 OVERDRAWING APPROPRIATION; PROOF OF CLAIMS.
   The Auditor shall not allow the amount set aside for any appropriation to be
overdrawn, or the amount appropriated for one item of expense to be drawn upon
for any other purpose, or allow a voucher to be paid unless sufficient funds
are in the Treasury to the credit of the fund upon which such voucher is drawn.
When any claim is presented to the Auditor, he or she may require evidence that
such amount is due, and for this purpose may summon any agent, clerk or
employee of the City, or any other person, and examine him or her upon oath or
affirmation concerning such voucher or claim.
(ORC 733.13)
236.05 DETAILED STATEMENTS OF RECEIPTS AND EXPENDITURES; APPROVAL OF VOUCHERS.
   On the first Monday of each month, detailed statements of the receipts and
expenditures of the officers and departments for the preceding month shall be
made to the Auditor by the heads of the departments. The Auditor shall
countersign each receipt given by the Treasurer before it is delivered to the
person entitled to receive it, and shall charge the Treasurer with the amount
thereof. If the Auditor approves any voucher contrary to the provisions of this
chapter, he or she and his or her sureties shall be individually liable for the
amount thereof.
(ORC 733.14; 1978 Code § 32.34)
236.06 CERTIFICATE AS TO ELECTION OF CERTAIN OFFICERS.
   The Auditor shall certify to the Court of Common Pleas the election of every
officer of the City having power to discharge the duties of a judge of a county
court, to take the acknowledgment of deeds, or to certify depositions or
affidavits to be used within the City, with the date of such election, and the
time when such officer became legally qualified to discharge the duties of such
office. Such certificate shall be made within ten days after such
qualification.
(ORC 733.15; 1978 Code § 32.35)
236.07 RECORDING OF CERTIFICATES BY CLERK.
   The Clerk of the Court of Common Pleas shall record the certificates
provided for in Section
236.06 in an appropriate record book. The same fees shall be allowed to the
officers certifying and recording them as are allowed under Ohio R.C. 2303.20
(R).
(ORC 733.16; 1978 Code § 32.36)
236.08 FORFEITURE FOR NEGLECT TO RECORD CERTIFICATE.
   If the Auditor who neglects or refuses to perform the duty required by
Section
236.06, he or she shall pay fifteen dollars ($15.00) to the Treasurer of the
City for each such neglect or refusal, to be recovered in a civil action, at
the suit of the City, and shall also be liable for all damages arising from
such neglect or refusal.
(ORC 733.17; 1978 Code § 32.37)
236.09 DUTY UPON RECEIPT OF BIDS.
   When bids are required to be filed for the letting of contracts by the
Director of Public Service and Safety, the Auditor or his or her chief deputy
shall attend and assist at the opening thereof and inspect them.
(ORC 733.18; 1978 Code § 32.38)
236.10 DEPUTY AUDITOR.
   The Auditor is hereby authorized to appoint a Deputy Auditor of the City who
shall perform the duties of the City Auditor during the disability of the
Auditor and during his or her absence from the City.
(Ord. 70-20. Passed 8-5-70.)
236.11 AUDITOR'S SEAL.
   Council shall provide a seal for the Auditor, in the center of which shall
be the name of the City, and around the margin the words "City Auditor," an
impression of which seal shall be affixed to all transcripts, orders,
certificates or other papers requiring authentication.
(ORC 733.20; 1978 Code § 32.40)
236.12 COMPLIANCE WITH ORDINANCES; ATTENDANCE AT COUNCIL MEETINGS.
   (a)   The Auditor shall comply with all ordinances of Council not
conflicting with his or her duties as prescribed by statute.
   (b)   If the Auditor determines it improper to comply with duties prescribed
by any City ordinance, he or she shall notify the President of Council, in
writing, giving notice of his or her noncompliance and his or her reasons for
the same. Upon request by the President of Council, at least three days
preceding a specified Council meeting, the Auditor shall attend the meeting.
(1978 Code § 32.41)
236.13 ENFORCEMENT AND EDUCATION FUND.
   (a)   The Auditor of the City is hereby authorized to establish an
Enforcement and Education Fund which shall be a special revenue fund in the
City accounts pursuant to the requirements of Substitute House Bill 837.
   (b)   The purpose of this Fund shall be to receive certain monies relating
to the enforcement of laws governing the operation of motor vehicles while
under the influence of alcohol.
(Ord. 90-62. Passed 12-19-90.)
236.14 INDIGENT DRIVERS ALCOHOL TREATMENT FUND.
   (a)   The Auditor of the City is hereby authorized to establish an Indigent
Drivers Alcohol Treatment Fund which shall be a special revenue fund in the
City accounts pursuant to the requirements of Ohio R.C. 4511.191.
   (b)   The purpose of this Fund shall be to receive certain monies from
appropriate courts and also from license fees relating to the enforcement of
laws governing the operation of motor vehicles while under the influence of
alcohol.
(Ord. 90-63. Passed 12-19-90.)
236.15   BLANKET PURCHASE ORDERS.
   (a)   The Council of the City of Wapakoneta hereby authorizes the use of
blanket purchase orders in accordance with Ohio Revised Code 5701.4l(D)(3).
   (b)   The Council of the City of Wapakoneta hereby establishes a blanket
purchase order amount limit not to exceed twenty five thousand dollars
($25,000.00) in accordance with Ohio Revised Code 5701.4l(D)(3).
(Ord. 2024-39. Passed 9-3-24.)

238.01 ELECTION; TERM; QUALIFICATIONS.
   The Treasurer shall be elected for a term of four years, commencing on the
first day of January next after his or her election. He or she shall be an
elector of the City.
(ORC 733.42; 1978 Code § 32.50)
238.02 ACCOUNTS.
   (a)   The Treasurer shall keep an accurate account of:
      (1)   All moneys received by him or her, showing the amount thereof, the
time received, from whom, and on what account received;
      (2)   All disbursements made by him or her, showing the amount thereof,
the time made, to whom, and on what account paid.
   (b)   He or she shall so arrange his or her books that the amount received
and paid on account of separate funds, or specified appropriations, shall be
exhibited in separate accounts. In addition to the ordinary duties of such
officer, he or she shall have such powers and perform such duties as may be
required by ordinance, not inconsistent with State law and not incompatible
with the nature of his or her office.
(ORC 733.43; 1978 Code § 32.51)
238.03 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Treasurer shall demand and receive from the County Treasurer taxes
levied and assessments made and certified to the County Auditor by the Council,
and placed on the tax list by the Auditor for collection, moneys from persons
authorized to collect or required to pay them, accruing to the municipality
from any judgments, fines, penalties, forfeitures, licenses and costs taxed in
Mayor’s Court, and debts due the municipality. These funds shall be disbursed
by the Treasurer and County Auditor on the order of any person authorized by
law or ordinance to issue orders therefor.
(R.C. § 733.44; 1978 Code §32.52)
238.04 QUARTERLY ACCOUNT; ANNUAL REPORT.
   The Treasurer shall settle and account with the Council, quarterly, and at
any other time which Council by resolution or ordinance requires. Each year, at
the first regular Council meeting in January, the Treasurer shall report to
Council the condition of finances of the City, the amount received by him or
her, the sources of such receipts, and the disbursements made by him or her,
and on what account, during the preceding year. The Treasurer's account shall
exhibit the balance due on each fund which has come into his or her hands
during the year.
(ORC 733.45; 1978 Code § 32.53)
238.05 RECEIPT AND DISBURSEMENT OF FUNDS.
   The Treasurer shall receive and disburse all City funds and other funds as
arise in or belong to any department or part of the City.
(ORC 733.46; 1978 Code § 32.54)
238.06 DUTY TO DELIVER MONEY AND PROPERTY.
   At the expiration of his or her term of office, or on his or her resignation
or removal, the Treasurer shall deliver to his or her successor all moneys,
books, papers and other property in his or her possession as Treasurer. In the
case of the death or incapacity of such Treasurer, his or her legal
representatives shall, in like manner, deliver the money and property which
were in the Treasurer's hands to the person entitled thereto.
(ORC 733.47; 1978 Code § 32.55)
238.07 DEPOSIT AND INVESTMENT POLICY.
   The deposit and investment policy of the City is hereby established as
follows:
   (a)   The Auditor and/or Treasurer are responsible for selecting
depositories and investing funds. The City, by State statute, shall limit
deposits and investments of City funds to insured demand deposit accounts,
certificates of deposit, United States Treasury bills or obligations of other
United States governmental agencies for which the principal and interest are
guaranteed by the United States Government and repurchase agreements.
Repurchase agreements shall not exceed a period of thirty days and must be
purchased from eligible financial institutions in the State. Certificates of
deposit shall be held in the name of the City by the issuing bank's trust
department.
   (b)   Active deposits are public deposits necessary to meet current demands
on the Treasury. Such moneys must be maintained either as cash in the City
Treasury, in commercial accounts payable or withdrawable on demand, including
negotiable order of withdrawal (NOW) accounts, or in money market deposit
accounts.
   (c)   Inactive deposits are public deposits that Council has identified as
not required for use within the current two-year period of designation of
depositories. Inactive deposits must be evidenced either by certificates of
deposit maturing not later than the end of the current period of designation of
depositories or by savings or deposit accounts, including, but not limited to,
passbook accounts.
   (d)   Interim deposits are deposits of interim moneys. Interim moneys are
those which are not needed for immediate use, but which will be needed before
the end of the current period of designation of depositories. Interim deposits
must be evidenced by time certificates of deposit maturing not more than one
year from the date of deposit, or by savings or deposit accounts, including
pass book accounts. Interim moneys may be invested in the following
obligations, provided that they mature or are redeemable within two years from
the date of purchase:
      (1)   Bonds, notes or other obligations of or guaranteed by the United
States pledged for the repayment of principal and interest;
      (2)   Bonds, notes, debentures or other obligations or securities issued
by a Federal government agency or instrumentality;
      (3)   Written repurchase agreements, for a period not to exceed thirty
days, in securities listed above that mature within five years from the date of
purchase;
      (4)   Bonds and other obligations of the State;
      (5)   No-load money market mutual funds consisting exclusively of
obligations described in paragraphs (d)(1) and (2) hereof and repurchase
agreements secured by such obligations, provided that investments in securities
described in this subsection are made only through eligible institutions; and
      (6)   The State Treasurer's investment pool (STAR Ohio).
   (e)   The City may also invest any moneys not required to be used for a
period of six months or more in the following:
      (1)   Bonds of the State;
      (2)   Bonds of any municipal corporation, village, county, township or
other political subdivision of the State, as to which there is no default of
principal, interest or coupons; and
      (3)   Obligations of the City.
   (f)   Protection for the City's deposits shall be provided by the Federal
Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC), by eligible securities pledged by the
financial institution as security for repayment, by surety bonds deposited with
the Treasurer by the financial institution or by a single collateral pool
established by the financial institution to secure the repayment of all public
monies deposited with the institution. Investments may only be made through
specified dealers and institutions. Payments for investments may be made only
upon the delivery of the securities representing the investments to the
Treasurer or, if the securities are not represented by certificate, upon
receipt of confirmation of transfer from the custodian.
(Res. 96-67. Passed 9-18-96.)
238.08 LIABILITY FOR LOSS OF PUBLIC FUNDS.
   The Treasurer, or other officer of the municipality having the duties of a
treasurer or of a city auditor, shall not be held liable for a loss of public
funds when the officer has performed all official duties required of the
officer with reasonable care, but shall be liable only when a loss of public
funds results from the officer's negligence or other wrongful act.
(R.C. § 733.82)

the first day of January next after his or her election. He or she shall be an
elector of the City.
(ORC 733.49; 1978 Code § 32.60)
240.02 ADDITIONAL QUALIFICATIONS.
   No person shall be eligible to the office of Law Director who is not an
attorney at law, admitted to practice in Ohio.
(ORC 733.50; 1978 Code § 32.61)
240.03 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Law Director shall prepare all contracts, bonds and other instruments in
writing in which the City is concerned, and shall serve the several directors
and officers mentioned in these Codified Ordinances as legal counsel and
attorney.
(ORC 733.51; 1978 Code § 32.62)
240.04 DUTIES CONCERNING SUITS.

prosecute or defend, as the case may be, on behalf of the City, all complaints,
suits and controversies in which the City is a party, and other suits, matters
and controversies as he or she shall, by resolution or ordinance, be directed
to prosecute. He or she shall not be required to prosecute any action before
the Mayor for the violation of an ordinance without first advising such action.
(ORC 733.53; 1978 Code § 32.63)

Department of Public Service and Safety
   EDITOR'S NOTE: The Department of Public Service and Safety comprises the

242.01 MERGER OF DEPARTMENTS.
   The Departments of Public Safety and of Public Service are hereby merged
into one department to be known as the Department of Public Service and Safety.
(1978 Code § 33.01)
242.02 ADMINISTRATION BY DIRECTOR.
   (a)   The Department of Public Service and Safety shall be administered by
the Director of Public Service and Safety.
   (b)   The Director shall be appointed by the Mayor. He or she need not be a
resident of the City at the time of his or her appointment but shall become a
resident within six months after his or her appointment, unless this
requirement is waived by ordinance. He or she shall make rules and regulations
for the administration of affairs under his or her supervision.
(ORC 735.01, 737.01; 1978 Code § 33.02)
242.03 GENERAL DUTIES OF DIRECTOR.
   (a)   Public Service Duties.
      (1)   The Director of Public Service and Safety shall manage and
supervise all public works and undertakings of the City, except as otherwise
provided by law.
      (2)   The Director shall supervise the improvement and repair of streets,
avenues, alleys, lands, lanes, squares, wharves, docks, landings, market
houses, bridges, viaducts, aqueducts, sidewalks, playgrounds, sewers, drains,
ditches, culverts, ship channels, streams and watercourses, the lighting,
sprinkling and cleaning of public places and the construction of public
improvements and public works, except as otherwise provided by law.
      (3)   The Director shall manage Municipal water, lighting, heating,
power, garbage and other undertakings of the City, and parks, baths,
playgrounds, market houses, cemeteries, crematories, sewage disposal plants and
farms, and shall make and preserve surveys, maps, plans, drawings and
estimates. He or she shall supervise the construction and have charge of the
maintenance of public buildings and other property of the City not otherwise
provided for in these Codified Ordinances. He or she shall have the management
of all other matters provided by the Council in connection with the public
service of the City.
      (4)   The Director shall keep a record of his or her proceedings, a copy
of which, certified by him or her, shall be competent evidence in all courts.
   (b)   Public Safety Duties. Under the Mayor's direction, the Director shall
be the executive head of the Police and Fire Departments. He or she shall have
all powers and duties connected with and incident to the appointment,
regulation and government of these Departments, except as otherwise provided by
law. He or she shall keep a record of his or her proceedings, a copy of which,
certified by him or her, shall be competent evidence in all courts. Such
Director shall make all contracts in the name of the City with reference to the
management of such Departments, for the erection or repair of all buildings or
improvements in connection therewith, and for the purchase of all supplies
necessary for such Departments.
(ORC 735.02, 737.02; 1978 Code § 33.03)
242.04 MANAGEMENT AND CONTROL OF OTHER EMPLOYEES; PRIVATE POLICE.
   The Director of Public Service and Safety shall have exclusive management
and control of all other officers, surgeons, secretaries, clerks and employees
as are provided by ordinance or resolution of Council. He or she may commission
private policemen, who may not be in the classified list of the Department,
under such rules and regulations as Council prescribes.
(ORC 737.05; 1978 Code § 33.04)
242.05 NONRESIDENT FIRE SERVICE.
   The Director of Public Service and Safety is hereby authorized to enter into
contracts and renew contracts in the future on behalf of the City, with such
political subdivisions or fire companies as he or she deems proper, providing
for the exchange of fire-fighting equipment and fire-fighters in the event of
an emergency.
(1978 Code § 33.05)

244.01 GENERAL DUTIES.
   The duties of the Police Department shall be to preserve the peace, protect
persons and property, obey and enforce all ordinances of Council and all
criminal laws of the State and the United States, and perform such other
duties, not inconsistent with these Codified Ordinances, as Council may
prescribe by ordinance.
(1978 Code § 35.01)
244.02 CHIEF OF POLICE.
   (a)   The Police Chief shall have exclusive control of the stationing and
transfer of all patrolmen and other officers and employees in the Police
Department, under general rules and regulations as the Director of Public
Service and Safety prescribes.
   (b)   The Police Chief shall be at least twenty-one years of age and during
service to the City shall reside either in Auglaize County, Ohio or in any
county immediately adjacent to Auglaize County in the State of Ohio.
(1978 Code §35.02; Ord. 2010-31. Passed 7-19-10)
244.03 POLICE DEPARTMENT PERSONNEL.
   (a)   In addition to the Director of Public Service and Safety and the
Police Chief, the Police Department shall be composed of command staff, which
may include lieutenants and sergeants assigned as determined by the Police
Chief and approved by the Director of Public Service and Safety. The Police
Department shall also be composed of patrol officers and dispatcher/clerks
assigned as determined by the Police Chief and approved by the Director of
Public Service and Safety. Part-time officers, auxiliary officers, part-time
dispatcher/clerks, code enforcement personnel, and non-sworn cadets are
permitted if requested by the Police Chief and approved by the Director of
Public Service and Safety.
   (b)   The making of an assignment by the Chief of one or more officers or
command staff to an investigative division shall not be construed as disturbing
the composition of the Police Department or seen as a promotion.
   (c)   A person between the ages of twenty-one years and thirty-six years,
inclusive, may receive an original appointment as an officer in the Police
Department.
   (d)   All officers and other members as are specified by ordinance shall,
during service to the City, reside either in Auglaize County, Ohio or in any
county immediately adjacent to Auglaize County in the State of Ohio.
(1978 Code §35.03; Ord. 75-27. Passed 5-21-75; Ord. 2010-32R. Passed 7-19-10;
Ord. 2-24-40. Passed 11-4- 24.)
244.04 PRIVATE POLICE AND AUXILIARY POLICE UNIT.
   (a)   The Police Chief, with the approval of the Director of Public Service
and Safety, when good cause exists, may appoint a special patrolman or night
watchman for the protection of private residential or business properties,
areas or establishments, provided that such appointees shall receive no
compensation from the Municipality and shall have first given bond to the City
in the amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000). Appointees shall have patrolman
powers and, while on duty, may wear police uniforms and insignia and carry arms
which the Director may prescribe. Appointment may be rescinded at any time by
the Police Chief or by resolution of Council.
   (b)   The Auxiliary Police Unit shall be within the Wapakoneta City Police
Department. The Director of Public Service and Safety shall be the executive
head of the Auxiliary Police Unit, shall make all appointments and removals of
Auxiliary Police Officers, subject to any general rules prescribed by Council,
and shall prescribe rules for the organization, training, administration,
control and conduct of the Auxiliary Police Unit. Members of the Unit shall
have patrol powers and, while on duty, may wear police uniforms and insignia
and carry approved firearms. The Chief of Police shall have exclusive control
of the stationing and transfer of all members of the Auxiliary Police Unit
under such general rules and regulations as the Director may prescribe. Members
of the Auxiliary Police Unit shall receive compensation in accordance with the
provisions of Section
260.31 upon the approval of the Chief of Police. Members of the Auxiliary
Police Unit shall not be in the classified service of the City. The Director of
Public Service and Safety shall determine the number of members of the
Auxiliary Police Unit.
(Ord. 91-73. Passed 12-18-91.)
244.05 SPECIAL PATROLMEN.
   In case of riot or other like emergency, the Mayor may appoint additional
patrolmen and officers for temporary service, who need not be in the classified
list of the Police Department. The additional officers or patrolmen shall be
employed only for the time during which the emergency exists.
(ORC 737.10; 1978 Code § 35.05)

246.01 GENERAL DUTIES.
   The Fire Department shall protect the lives and property of the people in
case of fire and shall perform such other duties, not inconsistent with these
Codified Ordinances, as Council may prescribe by ordinance.
(1978 Code § 35.01)
246.02 FIRE CHIEF.
   (a)   The Chief of the Fire Department shall have exclusive control of the
stationing and transferring of all fire-fighters and other officers and
employees in the Department, under such general rules and regulations as the
Director of Public Service and Safety prescribes.
   (b)   In case of riot or other like emergency, the Mayor may appoint
additional fire-fighters and officers for temporary service who need not be in
the classified list of the Department. The additional officers or fire-fighters
shall be employed only for the time during which the emergency exists.
   (c)   The Fire Chief shall be at least twenty-one years of age and during
service to the City shall reside either in Auglaize County, Ohio or in any
county immediately adjacent to Auglaize County in the State of Ohio.
(1978 Code §35.20; Ord. 2010-33. Passed 7-19-10)
246.03 COMPOSITION; AGE RANGE FOR ORIGINAL APPOINTMENTS; TRAINING AND
CERTIFICATION OF EMT'S.
   (a)   In addition to the Director of Public Service and Safety and the Chief
of the Fire Department, the Fire Department shall be composed of such officers
and other members as are specified by ordinance.
   (b)   A person between the ages of eighteen years and thirty-six years,
inclusive, may receive an original appointment as fire-fighter in the Fire
Department.
   (c)   A person receiving an original appointment as fire-fighter in the Fire
Department shall be required to take appropriate training and satisfactorily
complete all necessary examinations to become a certified Emergency Medical
Technician-Basic (EMT-B) within twelve months of his or her initial appointment
date and furthermore, shall be required to achieve and maintain certification
as an Emergency Medical Technician-Paramedic (EMT-P) within thirty-six months
of his or her initial appointment date. Fire-fighters who are unsuccessful in
achieving and maintaining said certification within the time frames allotted
shall be subject to disciplinary action up to and including dismissal.
   (d)   All officers, firefighters, and other members as are specified by
ordinance, shall during service to the City reside either in Auglaize County,
Ohio or in any county immediately adjacent to Auglaize County in the State of
Ohio.
(Ord. 2000-28. Passed 6-7-00; Ord. 2010-34. Passed 7-19-10.)
246.04 SCHOOLING OF OFFICERS AND FIRE-FIGHTERS.
   The Council may send any officers and fire-fighters of the Fire Department
to schools of instruction designed to promote efficiency of fire-fighters and,
if duly authorized in advance, may pay their necessary expenses from the funds
used for the maintenance and operation of the Fire Department.
(ORC 737.23; 1978 Code § 35.22)
246.05 AUTHORITY OF COUNCIL RE FIRE PROTECTION.
   Council may establish all necessary regulations to guard against the
occurrence of fires and to protect the property and lives of citizens against
damage and accidents resulting therefrom, and for such purposes may establish
and maintain a Fire Department, provide for the establishment and organization
of fire engine and hose companies and rescue units, establish the hours of
labor of the members of the Fire Department, who shall not be required to be on
duty continuously more than six days in every seven, and provide such bylaws
and regulations for the government of such companies and their members as are
necessary and proper.
(ORC 737.21)
246.06 PRACTICE FIRE DRILLS.
   The Fire Chief shall hold a monthly practice drill of at least one hour's
duration for the Fire Department, when the weather permits, and give
instructions in approved methods of fire fighting and fire prevention.
(1978 Code § 35.24)
246.07 RECORD OF FIRES.
   The Fire Chief shall keep in convenient form a complete record of all fires.
This record shall include the time of the alarm, the location of the fire,
cause of fire, if known, the type of building, the name of the owner and
tenant, the purpose for which occupied, the value of the building and contents,
members of the Department responding to the alarm, and such other information
as he or she deems advisable, or which is required, from time to time, by
Council.
(1978 Code § 35.25)
246.08 INVESTIGATIONS OF FIRES.
   Council may invest any officer of the Fire Department or the Police
Department with the power, and impose on him or her the duty, to be present at
all fires, investigate the causes thereof, examine witnesses and compel their
attendance and the production of books and papers, and do and perform all other
acts necessary to the effective discharge of such duties.
(ORC 737.27)
246.09 POWER TO MAKE ARRESTS.
   The officer invested with the power described in Section
246.08 shall have the power to administer oaths, make arrests and enter, for
the purpose of examination, any building which, in his or her opinion, is in
danger from fire, and he or she shall report his or her proceedings to the
Council at such times as may be required.
(ORC 737.27; 1978 Code § 35.27)
246.10 ANSWERING CALLS NOT COVERED BY RECIPROCAL AGREEMENTS.
   In the event an emergency fire call is received from any municipality with
which no contract has been entered into with the City, the Fire Chief or the
duty officer may exercise his or her judgment as to whether the call shall be
answered, and if so, what equipment and fire-fighters shall be used in
answering the call.
(1978 Code § 35.28)
246.11 MAINTENANCE OF DEPARTMENT GROUNDS.
   The Fire Chief and departmental members shall maintain and keep in good
order Fire Department grounds, sidewalks and buildings.
(1978 Code § 92.04)

   The following rates and charges for users of the Wapakoneta Emergency
Medical Service (EMS) are hereby adopted. These rates and charges shall apply
to all users of said service within the entire service territory, including
contracted areas outside the corporate limits of the City of Wapakoneta.
   RATES PER INCIDENT
 
Basic Life Support (B.L.S.)                   $600.00*
Advanced Life Support1 (A.L.S.1)              $750.00*
Advanced Life Support2 (A.L.S.2)              $900.00*
* Mileage: $14.40 per loaded mile as defined.
 
   (b)   The rates herein above established shall be adjusted annually on
January 1 to include increases established and approved by Medicare index for

(Ord. 2007-46. Passed 11-5-07; Ord. 2012-55. Passed 1-7-13; Ord. 2015-26.
Passed 8-17-15; Ord. 2015- 44. Passed 11-2-15.)
248.011 EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICE BILLING.
   (a)   Definitions. As used in this section and for reimbursement purposes,
the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectfully ascribed
to them as follows:
      (1)   “Basic Life Support (BLS).” Transportation by ground ambulance
vehicle and the provision of medically necessary supplies and services,
including BLS ambulance services as defined by the State. The ambulance must be
staffed by individuals who are qualified in accordance with State and local
laws as an emergency medical technician- basic (EMT-Basic). These laws may vary
from state to state or within a state. For example, only in some jurisdictions
is an EMT-Basic permitted to operate limited equipment onboard the vehicle,
assist more qualified personnel in performing assessments and interventions,
and establish a peripheral intravenous (IV) line.
      (2)   “Advanced Life Support, level 1 (ALS1).” The transportation by
ground ambulance vehicle and the provision of medically necessary supplies and
services, including the provision of an ALS assessment or at least one ALS
intervention. An advanced life support (ALS) assessment is an assessment
performed by an ALS crew as part of an emergency response that was necessary
because the patient's reported condition at the time of dispatch was such that
only an ALS crew was qualified to perform the assessment. An ALS assessment
does not necessarily result in a determination that the patient requires an ALS
level of service. An advanced life support (ALS) intervention is a procedure
that is in accordance with State and local laws, required to be done by an
emergency medical technician-intermediate (EMT-Intermediate) or EMT-Paramedic.
      (3)   “Advanced Life Support, Level 2 (ALS2). The transportation by
ground ambulance vehicle and the provision of medically necessary supplies and
services including: (1) at least three separate administrations of one or more
medications by intravenous push/bolus or by continuous infusion (excluding
crystalloid fluids); or (2) ground ambulance transport, medically necessary
supplies and services, and the provision of at least one of the ALS2 procedures
listed below:
         A.   Manual defibrillation/cardioversion;
         B.   Endotracheal intubation;
         C.   Central venous line;
         D.   Cardiac pacing;
         E.   Chest decompression;
         F.   Surgical airway; or
         G.   Intraosseous line.
      (4)   “Transport.” To carry or convey a person by a publicly owned and/or
operated motor vehicle being used in response to a call for emergency medical
assistance from one location to another.
      (5)   “Fees for Service.” The fee associated with the emergency
transportation of each individual requiring either basic life support or
advanced life support shall be the usual, customary and reasonable (UCR) charge
established by insurance companies within the region.
   (b)   Payment of Fee.
      (1)   No person shall be charged for basic life support or advanced life
support treatment unless he or she is transported by the City's Emergency
Medical Service.
      (2)   Every person being transported by the Emergency Medical Service or
some other person on behalf of that person being transported shall complete and
execute an assignment of benefits form at the time of such Emergency Medical
Service transport.
      (3)   If either the person being transported or some other person on
behalf of that person being transported, when, for any reason, the person being
transported is unable to execute an assignment of benefits form which entitles
the City to recover its Emergency Medical Service transportation fee directly
from the appropriate public or private insurer or any Federal, State or County
public welfare agency which may be responsible for paying the costs of treated
person's emergency transportation, the person being transported shall not be
held liable for all or any part of the fee forth above.
         A.   If the person being transported or some other person on behalf of
that person being transported provides incomplete, false or misleading
information which prevents the City from recovering upon its assignment of
benefits, the person being transported shall not be relieved of liability for
the fee set forth above until a complete, truthful and accurate assignment of
benefits form has been prepared, signed and presented to the Finance
Department.
         B.   If in spite of the completion of an assignment of benefits form,
the person being transported receives all or any part of the City's Emergency
Medical Service transportation fee, the person being transported shall not be
relieved of liability for such fee until he or she has remitted to the City all
moneys he or she received for payment of such fee for such Emergency Medical
Service.
      (4)   If the person being transported has no insurance and no other
payment source for the Emergency Medical Service fee exits, or if the
appropriate public or private insurer or Federal, State or County welfare
agency pays less than the full Emergency Medical Service fee, the balance still
due and owing for transportation of that person shall be waived by the City as
payment in full unless this provision violates any State or Federal law as it
pertains to the collection of fees.
   (c)   Establishment of Rates. It is hereby authorized and approved that the
third party administrator selected by the City shall establish the fee
submitted to the insurance carrier, determinate upon the level of the service
provided to the individual(s) being transported.
(Ord. 2007-46. Passed 11-5-07; Ord. 2012-55. Passed 1-7-13; Ord. 2015-26.
Passed 8-17-15; Ord. 2015- 44. Passed 11-2-15.)
248.02 COMPENSATION; PARTICIPATION IN OHIO PUBLIC EMPLOYEES RETIREMENT SYSTEM;
CLOTHING ALLOWANCE.
   (a)   Emergency Medical Technicians (E.M.T.s) and Emergency Rescue Drivers
(E.R.D.s) of the Wapakoneta EMS Auxiliary shall be paid for their services as
follows:
 
(1) Emergency Rescue Driver: $20.00 per run
    EMT - Basic:             $35.00 per run
    EMT - Advanced:          $35.00 per BLS Run $40.00 per ALS run
    EMT - Paramedic:         $35.00 per BLS Run $45.00 per ALS Run
 
      (2)   An additional ten dollars ($10.00) per run per E.M.T. for a
multiple victims run when transport is made.
      (3)   Thirty dollars ($30.00) per E.M.T. when called to the scene and
there is no transport to be made or a fire stand by run.
      (4)   Sixty cents ($.60) per hour for scheduled on-call time. On-call
rates will be $0.75 per hour for weekends and holidays. Specified holidays are
New Year's Day, Memorial Day, Fourth of July, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day, and
Christmas Day.
   (b)   E.R.D.s shall be required to participate in, and successfully
complete, the Ohio Emergency Vehicle Operations course. In addition, E.R.D.s
shall also successfully complete the coursework and maintain certification as a
First Responder.
   (c)   E.M.T.s and E.R.D.s are considered to be intermittent employees, as
defined in Section 123:1-47-01 of the Ohio Administrative Code, of the City,
and shall therefore be required to participate in the Public Employees
Retirement System (P.E.R.S.).
   (d)   E.M.T.s and E.R.D.s will be paid seven dollars and fifty cents ($7.50)
per hour for mandatory training.
   (e)   E.M.T.s will be paid seven dollars and fifty cents ($7.50) per hour
for manning the rescue squads during mandated events.
   (f)   In addition to the stated compensation, the City will furnish approved
clothing for the E.M.T.s and E.R.D.s as follows: New E.M.T.s and E.R.D.s
joining the EMS Auxiliary shall receive one three-season jacket and pant and
four shirts. Thereafter, worn or damaged items of uniform clothing will be
replaced at the City's expense at the discretion of the Fire Chief. In the
event that an E.M.T. or an E.R.D. resigns from or ceases to be active in the
EMS Auxiliary, he or she shall be required to turn in all items of uniform
clothing and any and all other property of the City in his or her possession to
the Fire Chief.
(Ord. 2000-27. Passed 6-7-00; Ord. 2001-37. Passed 7-18-01; Ord. 2003-18.
Passed 4-7-03; Ord. 2007-46. Passed 11-5-07; Ord. 2009-18. Passed 5-18-09; Ord.
2012-55. Passed 1-7-13; Ord. 2015-26. Passed 8-17- 15; Ord. 2015-44. Passed 11-
2-15.)

   The Director of Public Service and Safety shall adopt rules and regulations
for the operation of the Wapakoneta Emergency Medical Service.

250.01 ESTABLISHMENT.
   There is hereby established by and for the City, as a subdepartment within
the Department of Public Service and Safety, a Sewage Treatment Department.
(1978 Code § 52.01)
250.02 RESPONSIBILITIES.
   The Sewage Treatment Department shall be responsible for the operation and
maintenance of the sewage treatment and disposal plant and for the inspection
and regulation of the use of public and private sewers and drains, private
disposal systems, installations and connections of building sewers, and the
discharge of water and wastes into the public sewer system and natural outlets
in the City.
(1978 Code § 52.02)
250.03 SUPERINTENDENT.
   (a)   The position of Superintendent of the Sewage Treatment Department is
hereby established, and such position shall be within the classified civil
service. No person shall participate in the competitive examination for the
position of Superintendent who is not the qualified holder of a sewage plant
operator's rating of at least a "2" classification.
   (b)   The Superintendent shall be appointed by the Director of Public
Service and Safety from these persons on the eligible list for such position as
prepared by the Civil Service Commission of the City.
   (c)   The Superintendent shall be responsible for the administration of the
Sewage Treatment Department and the efficient operation and maintenance of the
sewage treatment and disposal plant. He or she shall enforce all ordinances and
regulations of the City, and all State laws, pertaining to the sewerage system,
private disposal systems and the treatment and disposal of all sewage and
industrial wastes within the City. He or she shall keep and maintain, at all
times, an accurate and complete map of the sewerage system of the City and
shall perform such other duties as may be prescribed by ordinance.
(1978 Code § 52.03)

258.01 ESTABLISHMENT; PURPOSE.
   There is hereby established in and for the City an Income Tax Department for
the purpose of collection of a Municipal income tax and to prepare the required
forms, collect pertinent data, audit completed returns and forms and maintain
files for the period required by regulation. Such revenues shall be deposited
in the General Fund under the designation of the City Income Tax Account.
(Ord. 76-60. Passed 11-3-76.)
258.02 CITY INCOME TAX ADMINISTRATOR.
   There is hereby established in and for the City the position of City Income
Tax Administrator.
(Ord. 76-60. Passed 11-3-76; Ord. 77-51. Passed 12-7-77; Ord. 2022-50. Passed
9-19-22.)
258.03 FUNDING FOR THE DEPARTMENT; COMPENSATION.
   (a)   The payment of salaries, supplies and equipment shall be made from the
City Income Tax Account.
   (b)   The salary of the combined position of City Income Tax Administrator
and Office Manager is established at an annual amount as set by Council.
   (c)   Such clerks as are required to assist in the efficient and orderly
operation of the Income Tax Department are authorized to be paid from the City
Income Tax Account.
(Ord. 76-60. Passed 11-3-76; Ord. 77-51. Passed 12-7-77.)
CHAPTER 260
Employees Generally
EDITOR'S NOTE: The City enters into Agreements from time to time with various
classes of Municipal employees, which Agreements provide for compensation,
benefits and other incidents of employment. The provisions of this chapter,
therefore, apply only to those employees and those subjects not otherwise
provided for in such Agreements. Copies of the latest relevant legislation, and
of such Agreements, may be obtained, at cost, from the Clerk of Council.
   A Personnel Policies and Procedures Manual and Job Description Manual, as
developed by Clemans, Nelson & Associates, was adopted by the City by
Resolution 2010-20, passed June 7, 2010. Copies of this resolution and of the
Manuals, as amended from time to time by Council, may be obtained, at cost,
from the Clerk of Council. A Public Records Policy was established and adopted,
and made part of the Personnel Policies and Procedures Manual by Ordinance
2007-54, passed November 5, 2007.
   Because of the frequency of change, provisions relating to regular
compensation are not codified. Copies of the latest relevant legislation may be
obtained, at cost, from the Clerk of Council.
   This chapter was repealed and re-enacted in its entirety by Ordinance 2006-
31, passed July 17, 2006.
260.01   Full-time and part-time employees defined.
