260.01 FULL-TIME AND PART-TIME EMPLOYEES DEFINED.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Full-time employee" means any Municipal employee who regularly works
at least 150 hours per month, but not including seasonal labor.
   (b)   "Part-time employee" means any Municipal employee who is not a full-
time employee.
(Ord. 2003-26. Passed 5-5-03; Ord. 2006-31. Passed 7-17-06.)
260.02 QUALIFICATIONS; OATHS.
   Each officer of the City, or of any department or board thereof, whether
elected or appointed as a substitute for a regular officer, shall be an elector
of the City, and before entering upon his or her official duties shall take an
oath to support the Constitutions of the United States and of Ohio, and an oath
that he or she will faithfully, honestly and impartially discharge the duties
of his or her office. These provisions concerning official oaths shall extend
to deputies, but they need not be electors.  
(ORC 733.68) (Ord. 2003-26. Passed 5-5-03; Ord. 2006-31. Passed 7-17-06.)
260.03 BONDS.
   (a)   Each officer required by law or ordinance to give bond shall do so
before entering upon the duties of the office, except as otherwise provided by
law. Council may, at any time, require each officer to give a new or additional
bond. Each bond, except that of the Auditor, upon its approval, shall be
delivered to the Auditor who shall immediately record it in a record provided
for that purpose and file and carefully preserve it in his or her office. The
bond of the Auditor shall be delivered to the Treasurer, who shall in like
manner record and preserve it.
(ORC 733.69)
   (b)   The official bonds of all Municipal officers shall be prepared by the
Law Director. Except as otherwise provided by law, they shall be in such sum as
the Council prescribes by general or special ordinances and shall be subject to
the approval of the Mayor. The Mayor's bond shall be approved by the Council,
or, if it is not legally organized, by the Clerk of the Court of Common Pleas
of Auglaize County.
(ORC 733.70)
   (c)   In each bond mentioned in subsection (b) hereof, the condition that
the person elected or appointed shall faithfully perform the duties of the
office shall be sufficient. The fact that the instrument is without a seal,
that blanks like the date or amount have been filled subsequent to its
execution but before its acceptance, without the consent of the sureties, that
all the obligees named in the instrument have not signed it, that new duties
have been imposed on the officers, or that any merely formal objection exists,
shall not be available in any suit on the instrument.
(ORC 733.71)
   (d)   The bond required of all City employees shall be as established by
Council. Bond provisions in effect as of the adoption of these Codified
Ordinances shall remain until modified or terminated.
   (e)   All City employees shall be bonded in the amount of five thousand
dollars ($5,000) each under the present blanket bond policy.
(Ord. 2003-26. Passed 5-5-03; Ord. 2006-31. Passed 7-17-06.)
260.04 UNIFORM RENTAL PROGRAM.
   (a)   The Director of Public Service and Safety and the Administrative
Assistant are hereby authorized to make payroll deductions on behalf of City
employees who sign up for a uniform rental program.
   (b)   The entire cost of said uniform rental shall be borne by the employees
who participate in the program.
   (c)   All employees who participate shall be required to sign an application
form which approves payroll deduction for this purpose and also allows the City
to withhold funds from the employee's final check to pay any outstanding
uniform rental obligations if the employee resigns, retires or is terminated.
   (d)   The Mayor may authorize uniform rental fees to be covered by the City
for certain positions as deemed appropriate.
(Ord. 2003-26. Passed 5-5-03; Ord. 2006-31. Passed 7-17-06; Ord. 2024-54.
Passed 1-6-25.)
260.05 CLOTHING ALLOWANCE FOR MEMBERS OF POLICE AND FIRE DEPARTMENTS.
   (a)   The City shall provide the Police Chief, police dispatchers and the
Fire Chief with an initial set of clothing (hereinafter referred to as initial
issue), as each initial issue is designated and described in the Wapakoneta
Police Department Uniform Dress Code, and the Wapakoneta Fire Department Rules
and Regulations, with said initial issue to be provided upon such new member
being sworn into service in said department.
   (b)   The City shall allot the following annual uniform and clothing
allowance as follows:
During the calendar year following the year of entry into service with the
City, and annually thereafter, the following allowances will be paid from the
General Fund:
 
Police Chief $500.00
Fire Chief   $500.00
 
   (c)   The Auditor shall pay said allowance and for said initial issue,
according to the provisions of this section, to the credit of each member of
the Police and Fire Departments, when vouchers are properly presented to the
Auditor for payment.
(Ord. 2004-33. Passed 7-8-04; Ord. 2006-31. Passed 7-17-06; Ord. 2006-42.
Passed 9-4-06; Ord. 2011-31. Passed 7-11-11; Ord. 2013-18. Passed 6-3-13; Ord.
2024-54. Passed 1-6-25.)
260.06 DIRECT DEPOSIT.
   (a)   The Director of Public Service and Safety and the Administrative
Assistant are hereby authorized to make direct deposits on behalf of employees
into their designated accounts.
   (b)   All employees must participate and shall be required to sign an
authorization form authorizing the City to deposit payroll earnings into the
accounts listed by the employee.
(Ord. 2003-26. Passed 5-5-03; Ord. 2006-31. Passed 7-17-06.)
260.07 POSITION CLASSIFICATION PLAN.
   (a)   The position classification plan provides for the classification of
each employment position in the City, so that personnel problems may be dealt
with as systematically and equitably as possible, and so that the principle of
"equal pay for equal work" may be observed.
   (b)   The plan shall be used:
      (1)   As an aid in the determination of lines of promotion;
      (2)   In defining payroll items in several departments and fund budgets;
and
      (3)   In determining salaries for various types of work.
   (c)   Development of the position classification plan is as follows: The
Director of Public Service and Safety shall be responsible for the proper and
continuous maintenance of the classification plan so that it will reflect on a
current basis the duties being performed by each employee of the City and the
class to which each position is allocated. Revisions of the class
specifications and reallocations within the classification plan shall be as
follows:
      (1)   The Director of Public Service and Safety shall study the duties
and responsibilities of each new position as it is created and, on the basis of
that study, place the position in the appropriate class within the
classification plan.
      (2)   Changes in the duties or responsibilities of any position involving
either the addition of new assignments or the taking away or modification of
existing assignments shall be reported to the Director of Public Service and
Safety by the department heads. If these changes are determined to be permanent
or more than minor changes, and justify reallocation to a different
classification, the Director of Public Service and Safety shall place such
position in its appropriate classification. Reallocations involving civil
service shall be reported to the Civil Service Commission by the Director of
Public Service and Safety so that its rules and regulations may be followed as
required.
      (3)   The Director of Public Service and Safety shall periodically review
the classification of positions and, on the basis of such review, may combine,
abolish or, if necessary, upon approval of the City Council, establish new
classifications.
      (4)   The Director of Public Service and Safety, as chief administrative
officer, shall be the appointing authority for all positions in the Department
of Public Service and Safety. The responsibility for the maintenance of a
superior degree of efficiency, discipline and morale is that of the Director of
Public Service and Safety, and the Director may remove from the City service
any employees appointed by him or her and shall exercise control and
supervision over all subdepartments and classifications in the Department of
Public Service and Safety. All new employees must complete an employment
application form prior to approval for employment and may be required to submit
to a physical examination by a competent physician designated by the City. The
expense of the examination will be borne by the City.
      (5)   Due to the nature of certain job duties or requirements, an
employee may be requested to live in Auglaize County or an adjacent county. The
employee will be informed of this at the time of employment.
      (6)   An employee may at any time submit a written request, through his
or her department head, to the Director of Public Service and Safety for a
review of the allocation of his or her position, setting forth the reasons for
justifying the review. The Director of Public Service and Safety shall make, or
cause to be made, an investigation of the position, with a view to determining
its correct allocation. The decision of the Director of Public Service and
Safety shall be reported to the employee.
(Ord. 2003-26. Passed 5-5-03; Ord. 2006-31. Passed 7-17-06; Ord. 2024-54.
Passed 1-6-25.)
260.08 COMPENSATION.
   The salary to be paid to all City employees shall be as established by
Council.
(Ord. 2003-26. Passed 5-5-03; Ord. 2006-31. Passed 7-17-06; Ord. 2007-26.
Passed 7-2-07; Ord. 2012-32. Passed 6-18-12; Ord. 2012-40. Passed 9-5-12; Ord.
2013-04(R). Passed 2-18-13; Ord. 2013-16. Passed 6-3-13; Ord. 2017-12. Passed
4-17-17.)
260.09 SALARIES NOT TO BE CHANGED DURING TERM; DEPOSIT OF FEES.
   The salary of any officer shall not be increased or diminished during the
term for which he or she was elected or appointed, and, except as otherwise
provided in these Codified Ordinances, all fees pertaining to any office shall
be paid into the City Treasury. This section does not prohibit the payment of
any increased costs of continuing to provide the identical benefits provided to
an officer at the commencement of his or her term of office.
(ORC 731.07) (Ord. 2003-26. Passed 5-5-03; Ord. 2006-31. Passed 7-17-06.)
260.10 PAY PLAN.
   (a)   The minimum rate of pay for a class shall be paid upon appointment to
the class, except that appointment rates above the minimum rate may be paid by
the Director of Public Service and Safety. The department head may submit a
request, outlining reasons for such action, for approval by the Director of
Public Service and Safety. Justification for approval will be limited to
recognition of exceptional qualifications or experience of an eligible
employee, or lack of available eligible employees at the minimum rate. If a
former employee is re-employed in a class in which he or she has previously
been employed, the Director of Public Service and Safety may make an
appointment at the same rate of pay which the employee had been receiving at
the termination of his or her service if that rate is at or above the
established minimum rate at the time of re-employment.
   (b)   Increases within appropriate ranges shall be from one step to the next
higher step. Except for the position of Director of Public Service and Safety,
the employee must have completed six months at the lower pay range when
advancing from Step 1 to Step 2. Except for the position of Director of Public
Service and Safety, the employee must have completed one year at the lower pay
range before advancing from Step 2 to Step 3, from Step 3 to Step 4, and from
Step 4 to Step 5. However, if it is determined that an employee is improperly
classified, or in the case of a promotion, the provision that an employee must
have completed not less than twelve months at the next lower pay range may be
waived by the Director of Public Service and Safety. If an employee, other than
the Director of Public Service and Safety, starts in a step other than Step 1,
he or she is eligible to advance to the next step in six months.
   The Director of Public Service and Safety shall advance to the next step on
January 1 of each year subsequent to the date of his or her appointment.
   (c)   Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (b) hereof, salary
increases of more than one step or more frequently than specified may be made
by the Director of Public Service and Safety on recommendation from the
department head, in exceptional circumstances.
   (d)   Each step of the five-step salary and hourly range shall not be
considered automatic. The department head must justify to the Director of
Public Service and Safety and the employee the denial or approval of an
increase on the basis of the employee's job performance.
      (1)   Each new employee shall be regarded as probationary for a period of
six months. After such probationary period, the employee is advanced to the
next step or is not retained as an employee.
      (2)   The employee is expected to constantly develop his or her ability.
Improvement may be attained by greater skill in performing assigned tasks,
increased work effort and satisfactory completion of work relating to the
position.
   (e)   Employees appointed to City positions may be assigned to any step
within the approved range as deemed appropriate by the Director of Public
Service and Safety. After a probationary period of six months, the employee may
be advanced to the next higher step. Advancement through these steps shall not
be considered automatic and will be made on the basis of positive employee
performance.
   (f)   Each year the Director of Public Service and Safety shall meet with
the heads of the various departments and shall compile a personnel evaluation
and review of the department heads. The Director then shall make
recommendations to City Council as to salary increases and/or benefit
adjustments which should be made in the pay plan. Personnel evaluations shall
generally take place during the fourth quarter of each year such that
adjustments to wages and benefits can be considered and made effective during
the proceeding January of the next calendar year.
(Ord. 2003-26. Passed 5-5-03; Ord. 2006-31. Passed 7-17-06; Ord. 2022-75.
Passed 1-16-23; Ord. 2024-54. Passed 1-6-25.)
260.11 DEVELOPMENT AND MAINTENANCE OF SALARY AND HOURLY RANGES.
   (a)   Salary and hourly ranges shall be linked directly to the plan of
position classification and shall be determined with due regard to ranges of
pay for other classes, relative difficulty and responsibility of positions in
the class, availability of employees in particular occupational categories, and
other related considerations. The minimum, maximum and intermediate steps of
each range shall be those rates in the standard salary and hourly schedule
which most nearly reflect these factors.
   (b)   Annually, the Director of Public Service and Safety shall meet and
confer with the Finance Committee of City Council for the purpose of reviewing
and recommending, with the Mayor, changes in this section to the City Council.
(Ord. 2003-26. Passed 5-5-03; Ord. 2006-31. Passed 7-17-06; Ord. 2024-54.
Passed 1-6-25.)
260.12 TOTAL REMUNERATION.
   (a)   The salary rate, plus reimbursement for automobile expense, uniforms,
official travel and any special provisions outlined in this pay plan, shall be
the total remuneration of the employee. Except as herein provided, no employee
shall receive pay from the City in addition to that authorized under the
schedule provided in the pay plan for services rendered by him or her in the
discharge of his or her duties or of any additional duties which may be imposed
upon him or her or which he or she may undertake or volunteer to perform.
   (b)   City services are not to be extended by employees in exchange for
special rewards, gifts or other remuneration from outside individuals or
organizations.
(Ord. 2003-26. Passed 5-5-03; Ord. 2006-31. Passed 7-17-06.)
260.13 PART-TIME WORK.
   Whenever a part-time employee works for a period less than the regularly
established number of hours a day, days a week, or weeks a month, the amount
paid shall be in proportion to the time actually employed for this class,
unless special circumstances require revisions of the rate. Such revision shall
be subject to the approval of the Director of Public Service and Safety or the
responsible City official.
(Ord. 2003-26. Passed 5-5-03; Ord. 2006-31. Passed 7-17-06.)
260.14 OVERTIME.
   (a)   Approval of overtime work and overtime pay shall be as follows:
      (1)   Except in cases of true emergency, overtime requirements shall be
scheduled by the department head, and prior approval must be secured from the
Director of Public Service and Safety.
      (2)   In cases of true emergency, overtime work and overtime pay shall be
authorized by the department head or such authorization is to be made under
general guidelines specified in advance by the Director, and the department
head is responsible to the Director for its judicious use.
   (b)   Budgeted funds must be available for payment of overtime work.
      (1)   Full-time employees will be compensated for approved scheduled and
approved emergency overtime beyond regular shift hours in any one day and the
established work week, at one and one-half times the average hourly rate. Sick
leave benefits will not be considered as regular shift hours, unless the hours
are used for a pre-planned appointment and an accompanying form is submitted.
      (2)   Employees may be given compensatory time off in lieu of cash as
payment for overtime. However, one and one-half hours of compensatory time must
be given for each hour of overtime worked.
      (3)   When employees attend mandatory training courses and/or meetings
approved in writing by the Director of Public Service and Safety, while not on
regular duty for the City of Wapakoneta, the employee shall be compensated at
his or her overtime rate of pay, if the time qualifies as overtime as described
in this section.
   (c)   When an employee is transferred at the City's request to a
classification other than his or her regular job duties, he or she shall
receive the higher of his or her regular pay or the pay for the job
classification to which he or she is transferred.
   Any employee requesting a transfer to another job classification which meets
with the approval of the Director of Public Service and Safety shall receive
wage rates of the classification to which he or she is transferred.
(Ord. 2003-26. Passed 5-5-03; Ord. 2006-31. Passed 7-17-06; Ord. 2024-54.
Passed 1-6-25.)
260.15 EXEMPTIONS FROM PROVISIONS RE PART-TIME AND OVER-TIME WORK.
   (a)   The following employees of the City shall be exempt from Sections
260.13 and
260.14. Classifications in this section are designated as supervisory
personnel.
Classification Pay Basis
Classification                         Pay Basis
Fire Chief                             Yr.
Police Chief                           Yr.
Office Manager                         Yr.
Income Tax Administrator               Yr.
HR Manager                             Yr.
Superintendent of Engineering          Yr.
Superintendent of Public Works         Yr.
Superintendent of Wastewater Treatment Yr.
Superintendent of Water Treatment      Yr.
Superintendent of Electric             Yr.
Director of Public Service and Safety  Yr.
 
   (b)   Salary employees are not eligible for overtime, but may earn flexible
time on an hour for hour basis beyond any established work week.
   (c)   The Director of Public Service and Safety shall be appointed by the
Mayor. All other employees set forth in subsection (a) hereof shall be
appointed by the Mayor with the advice of the Director of Public Service and
Safety.
   (d)   City employees who are represented by the collective bargaining unit
of the Utility Worker's Union of America, the Ohio Patrolmen's Benevolent
Association and the International Association of Firefighters, are hereby
exempted from the terms and conditions of this chapter.
(Ord. 2003-26. Passed 5-5-03; Ord. 2006-31. Passed 7-17-06; Ord. 2024-54.
Passed 1-6-25.)
260.16 GROUP INSURANCE, TRAVEL EXPENSES AND OTHER REIMBURSEMENTS.
   (a)   Travel expense reimbursement shall be as follows:
      (1)   All reimbursement for use of private automobiles by any and all
municipal officers and employees for City convenience on authorized trips shall
be at the rate of the current mileage allowance per IRS guidelines.
      (2)   All out-of-City trips by employees of the Departments of Public
Service and Safety, for which compensation will be paid, must first be approved
by the Director of Public Service and Safety.
      (3)   Reimbursement for reasonable expenses for personal needs, lodging,
transportation costs, and other justifiable travel expenses on authorized trips
beyond twenty miles of the City by an employee in the Departments of Public
Service and Safety will be authorized and approved by the Director.
      (4)   Authorization for travel expense reimbursement for trips outside
the City by City officials shall be made by the Mayor in compliance with the
Ohio Revised Code. Reimbursement shall conform to the provisions of paragraphs
(a)(1), (2) and (3) hereof.
      (5)   Authorization for issuance of advance funds for travel expenses
when requested will be given by the Director for Departments of Public Service
and Safety employees and by the Mayor for City officials.
      (6)   Reimbursement for all out-of-pocket expenses shall be made with a
receipt exclusive of mileage charges as provided in paragraph (a)(1) hereof.
   (b)   Group hospitalization insurance, including medical coverage and
prescription drug will be provided for the employee and the employee's
dependents as defined by the plan. The City will pay eighty percent of the
monthly premium for individual or family coverage for each full-time non-
bargaining unit employee. The employee will pay twenty percent of the monthly
premium for individual or family coverage. The City may offer alternative
insurance plans to employees for which the seventy-five percent to twenty- five
percent premium cost share shall apply. The City may also offer a Health
Savings Account (HAS) for voluntary participation (effective January 1, 2012).
   (c)   The City shall provide and pay for a thirty thousand dollar ($30,000)
group term life insurance, including a thirty thousand dollar ($30,000)
accidental death policy, covering all full-time non- bargaining unit employees.
   (d)   All full-time City employees shall, on a voluntary basis, be provided
the opportunity to become vaccinated with the Hepatitis B vaccine. The City
shall pay for the vaccine and vaccination when requested to do so, in writing,
by the employee.
   (e)   All employees shall receive, and are expected to give a minimum of two
weeks notice of termination of employment. The two weeks notice of termination
of employment does not apply if the termination of employment is not under
honorable conditions, if a new employee's probationary period has not passed,
or if employment is for intermittent periods. Examples of termination under
other than honorable conditions are:
      (1)   Committing a felony;
      (2)   Intoxication on the job;
      (3)   Flagrant or persistent insubordination;
      (4)   Conduct subversive of proper order and discipline;
      (5)   Misuse of public funds or materials;
      (6)   Falsifying reports or records;
      (7)   Sustained conduct detrimental to the efficiency or morale of the
service; or
      (8)   Incompetence.
(Ord. 2003-26. Passed 5-5-03; Ord. 2003-46. Passed 7-7-03; Ord. 2006-31. Passed
7-17-06; Ord. 2010-18-R. Passed 5-17-10; Ord. 2011-53R. Passed 10-17-11; Ord.
2023-14. Passed 3-6-23; Ord. 2024-54. Passed 1-6-25.)
260.17 HOLIDAYS.
   (a)   All full-time non-bargaining unit employees who are covered by this
chapter shall receive the following recognized holidays off at their regular
rate of pay:
New Year's Day         Labor Day
Martin Luther King Day Columbus Day
President's Day        Veterans Day
Good Friday - ½ day   Thanksgiving
Memorial Day           Friday after Thanksgiving
Juneteenth             Christmas Eve - ½ day
Independence Day       Christmas Day
Employee Birthday: Administrative Assistant to Director of Safety & Service,
Fire/EMS Administrative Assistant, Zoning and Engineering Manager, Office
Manager, Human Resources Manager, Water Superintendent, Public Works
Superintendent, Tax Administrator, Wastewater Superintendent, Police Chief,
Fire Chief, Engineering Superintendent, Electric Superintendent and Director
of Service and Safety.
 
   The holiday shall be considered the day on which the holiday is celebrated
in the calendar year upon which it falls. Should the paid holiday fall on
Saturday or Sunday, the preceding Friday or the following Monday shall be given
off unless another date is agreed upon with the Director of Public Service and
Safety.
   (b)   Administrative Assistant to DSS, Fire/EMS Administrative Assistant,
Zoning and Engineering Manager, Office Manager, Human Resources Manager, Water
Superintendent, Public Works Superintendent, Tax Administrator, Wastewater
Superintendent, Police Chief, Fire Chief, Engineering Superintendent, Electric
Superintendent and Director of Service and Safety shall be given three
personal-leave days (twenty-four hours) each year. Said personal-leave day
shall be scheduled in accordance with the holiday scheduling policies and
procedures established for the City.
   (c)   Part-time employees, seasonal employees and temporary employees, are
not eligible for holiday pay, personal leave, sick leave and vacation pay.
   (d)   The Mayor may authorize more than a one-step increase, a lump sum
payment, or an amount up to that of a step increase for exceptional/or special
and meritorious performance by the employee. Such performance and pay
determinations shall be at the sole discretion of the employer.
(Ord. 2003-26. Passed 5-5-03; Ord. 2006-31. Passed 7-17-06; Ord. 2008-33.
Passed 7-21-08; Ord. 2010-35R. Passed 7-5-10; Ord. 2011-73. Passed 12-19-11;
Ord. 2012-03. Passed 1-9-12; Ord. 2012-32. Passed 6-18-12; Ord. 2012-40. Passed
9-5-12; Ord. 2013-04(R). Passed 2-18-13; Ord. 2013-16. Passed 6-3-13; Ord.
2014-13. Passed 5-19-14; Ord. 2015-16. Passed 5-18-15; Ord. 2016-06. Passed 4-
4-16; Ord. 2016-09. Passed 4-18-16; Ord. 2016-26. Passed 8-1-16; Ord. 2016-40.
Passed 12-5-16; Ord. 2017-12. Passed 4-17-17; Ord. 2019-20. Passed 5-6-19; Ord.
2020-25. Passed 6-15-20; Ord. 2021-16. Passed 4-19-21; Ord. 2022-22R. Passed 4-
4-22; Ord. 2022-52. Passed 9-19-22; Ord. 2022-76. Passed 1-16-23; Ord. 2023-
17R. Passed 4-17-23; Ord. 2023- 60R. Passed 12-18-23; Ord. 2024-14. Passed 3-
18-24; Ord. 2024-42. Passed 11-4-24.)
260.18 SICK LEAVE.
   (a)   Each full-time employee shall be entitled to 4.6 hours of sick leave
with pay for each completed eighty hours of service. Seasonal and part-time
employees shall not be eligible for sick leave benefits.
   (b)   Unused sick leave shall be cumulative without limit. When sick leave
is used, it shall be deducted from the employee's credit on the basis of one
hour for every one hour of absence from previously scheduled work.
   (c)   Sick leave may be granted only for absence from duty because of
personal illness, legal quarantine, injury off or on the job and death or
serious illness in the employee's or the employee's spouse's immediate family.
Immediate family shall be construed as being a husband, wife, father, mother,
sister, brother, son, daughter, grandparent, grandchild and other persons at
the discretion of the Director of Public Service and Safety.
   (d)   When an employee is unable to report for work for reasons set forth in
subsection (c) hereof, he or she shall, if possible, notify his or her
supervisor prior to the regular reporting time of his or her inability to
report for work. Failure to comply with this request shall be grounds for
disciplinary action.
   (e)   Each employee shall submit a satisfactory written, signed statement to
justify the use of sick leave. If medical attention is required, a certificate
stating the nature of the illness from a licensed physician shall be required.
Falsification of either a written signed statement or a physician's certificate
shall be grounds for disciplinary action up to and including dismissal. The
Director of Public Service and Safety may order any employee claiming an
illness or injury rendering him or her unable to perform his or her duties to
submit to an examination by a designated physician at the City's expense.
   (f)   While absent from work due to illness or injury an employee must
remain at home caring for his or her illness or injury or at a place receiving
medical attention (hospital, doctor's office, clinic, etc.) and be able to
document any absence from home. An authorized City representative may
investigate any absence from duty as a result of a claimed illness or injury.
   (g)   No sick leave benefits shall be paid for convalescence outside of
Auglaize County without prior written approval of the Director of Public
Service and Safety, unless the employee is a patient in a hospital or other
institution.
   (h)   Previously accumulated sick leave of an employee who has been
separated from the public service shall be placed to his or her credit upon his
or her re-employment in the public service, provided that re-employment takes
place within ten years of the date on which the employee was last terminated
from public service. An employee who transfers from another public agency to
this agency shall be credited with the unused balance of his or her accumulated
sick leave.
   (i)   A City employee hired prior to January 1, 1988, shall, at the time of
retirement from active service with the City, be paid one-half of the value of
his or her earned but unused sick leave credit. A City employee hired after
January 1, 1988, at the time of retirement from active service with the City,
shall be paid twenty-five percent of his or her accrued but unused sick leave,
up to a maximum of 260 accrued sick days (sixty-five days total maximum
payment). Payment of accrued but unused sick leave under an applicable
collective bargaining agreement shall supersede this policy. In either case, to
qualify for such payment, the employee shall have had, prior to the date of
retirement, ten or more years of service with the City, County, State or any of
its political subdivisions. Such payment shall be based on the employee's rate
of pay at the time of retirement. Such payment shall be made only once and
shall eliminate all sick leave credit accrued by the employee. An employee who
dies shall be eligible for such sick leave payment for which he or she would
otherwise have qualified effective as of the date of his or her death. Such
payment shall be made in accordance with Ohio R.C. 2113.04 or be paid to the
employee's estate.
   (j)   Sick leave benefits will not be paid without the completion of forms
provided by the City for sick leave benefits, which completed forms must have
proper signatures affixed thereto.
   (k)   Sick leave donation.
   Employees may receive and donate on a strictly voluntary basis accrued sick
leave hours from/to other employees of the City per the conditions of receipt
and donation identified herein.
   Hours are donated and received on an hour for hour basis and shall be paid
at the current rate of pay of the employee using the hours. All hours donated
but not used shall be returned to the original donor.
   Sick leave may be donated to employees for usage that qualifies for sick
leave use. In order to receive donated sick leave, the employee receiving the
hours must have exhausted all paid sick leave.
   Employees may donate sick leave hours in minimum blocks of one hour. While
an employee may donate to multiple employees eligible for donation, an employee
may donate a maximum of 40 hours to any one person per year.
(Ord. 2003-26. Passed 5-5-03; Ord. 2006-31. Passed 7-17-06; Ord. 2022-37.
Passed 6-20-22; Ord. 2024-54. Passed 1-6-25.)
260.19 VACATIONS.
   (a)   Definitions.
      (1)   As used in this section:
         A.   “Service” shall be in compliance with Ohio R.C. 9.44.
         B.   “Vacation year” means the twelve-month period commencing January
1 of any year and ending December 31 of the same year.
      (2)   A new employee whose employment date is other than January 1 shall
receive accrued vacation in the first partial year of employment pro rata
computed to the nearest month.
   (b)   Vacation Benefits.
      (1)   All full-time employees of the City whose jobs are not defined as
positions in a collective bargaining unit, and who have completed the following
years of service, shall, be entitled to vacation leave with pay as follows:
 
Length of Service                    Accrual Per Pay Period Annual Rate
Date of hire but less than 5 years   3.1 hours              80 hours
5 full years but less than 10 years  4.6 hours              120 hours
10 full years but less than 15 years 6.2 hours              160 hours
15 full years but less than 20 years 6.9 hours              180 hours
20 full years and over               7.7 hours              200 hours
 
      (2)   All employees, regardless of date of hire, will be compensated for
eligible vacation time in accordance with their current salary at the time the
vacation is taken.
      (3)   Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (a) hereof, the
Director of Public Service and Safety, at the date of appointment, shall be
immediately eligible for vacation benefits as established by the Appointing
Authority.
   (c)   Employees shall be permitted to carry over from calendar year to
calendar year two times the employee's annual accrual rate. Further carry over
will not be permitted when the maximum is reached. Vacation credits are not
earned while an employee is in a non-paid status (i.e., non-paid disability
leave, leave of absence without pay, leave of absence due to Worker's
Compensation injury, disciplinary suspension, etc.).
   Not more than three consecutive weeks of vacation may be scheduled without
the prior written approval of the Director of Public Service and Safety.
   Insofar as practical, every effort will be made to schedule vacations at the
time most preferable to each employee. However, final decision with respect to
the scheduling of vacations shall rest with the Director of Public Service and
Safety and must be geared to the City's need for the employee's services.
   (d)   General Provisions.
   If an employee dies, is inducted into military service for a period
exceeding six months, retires, is discharged, or is terminated due to a
reduction in staff, such employee shall be paid for any accrued vacation time
earned during previous vacation years, plus any pro rata vacation time earned
during the current vacation year computed to the nearest month.
   If a recognized holiday as defined in Section
260.17(a) falls within an employee's paid and approved vacation period, the
employee shall receive payment for the holiday and the day shall not be
deducted from the employee's vacation balance.
   Upon separation from the city, an employee shall be entitled to compensation
at the employee's current rate of pay for all lawfully accrued and unused
vacation leave to the employee's credit at the time of separation.
   Vacation benefits shall not be paid without completion of a vacation form
and proper approval of the same.
   (e)   Vacation Donation.
   Employees may receive and donate on a strictly voluntary basis accrued
vacation leave hours from/to other employees of the City per the conditions of
receipt and donation identified herein.
   Hours are donated and received on an hour for hour basis and shall be paid
at the current rate of pay of the employee using the hours. All hours donated
but not used shall be returned to the original donor.
   In order to receive donated vacation leave, the employee receiving hours
must have exhausted all paid leave time not including sick leave. Employees may
donate vacation leave hours in minimum blocks of one hour. While an employee
may donate to multiple employees eligible for donation an employee may donate a
maximum of 40 hours to any one person per calendar year.
(Ord. 2003-26. Passed 5-5-03; Ord. 2006-31. Passed 7-17-06; Ord. 2009-30-R.
Passed 8-3-09; Ord. 2013-17. Passed 6-3-13; Ord. 2024-54. Passed 1-6-25.)
260.20 LAYOFFS; SENIORITY; LONGEVITY COMPENSATION.
   (a)   All employees covered by this chapter shall enjoy the following
seniority rights: When, due to lack of work, it becomes necessary to lay off
employees, the employee with the least seniority standing in the occupational
group shall be the first to be laid off, and when employees are recalled, the
first to be recalled shall be those last laid off, provided that the employee
recalled has previously performed or is capable of doing work then available.
Seniority shall be by occupational group or department, starting from the first
date of employment with the group or department on work covered herein, except
that should an employee have left the service due to discharge for cause,
resignation or being on lay-off and refusing to return to work within five days
after having been notified to do so, and being later re-employed, the
employee's seniority standing shall date from the date of the re-employment.
   (b)   Non-bargaining unit full-time employees of the City, with five or more
years of continuous employment with the City, shall receive, in addition to his
or her regular salary or hourly wage, additional compensation at the following
rates:
         Years of Service         Rates
      Fewer than 5 years of service      $0
      5 full years of service         $250
   Adding fifty dollars ($50.00) additional each year thereafter of continuous
service.
   This additional compensation shall be accumulated by the City and shall be
paid to employees on the first pay day in December of each year.
   In the event an employee terminates his or her employment with the City, his
or her longevity pay provided herein shall be prorated over the period of
employment in the year of termination.
   “Continuous employment,” as used in this section, means full-time employment
by the City, including regular vacation and sick leave time.
   Such continuous employment shall commence at the employee's most recent date
of employment. Such longevity pay shall be computed and go into effect on the
first day of the first full pay period after the anniversary date of such
employment, assuming that time and continuous employment provisions are met.
(Ord. 2003-26. Passed 5-5-03; Ord. 2006-31. Passed 7-17-06; Ord. 2024-54.
Passed 1-6-25.)
260.21 LEAVES OF ABSENCE.
   A leave of absence without pay for a period not to exceed thirty days may be
granted for reasons subject to the prior approval of the Director of Public
Service and Safety, provided that the employee shall not engage in gainful
employment either in the services of another employer or through self-
employment, and provided that the employee can be spared from his or her
occupation for the period of such leave without the necessity of a replacement.
Full credit for continuous service shall be given.
(Ord. 2003-26. Passed 5-5-03; Ord. 2006-31. Passed 7-17-06.)
260.22 EMPLOYEE COMPLAINTS AND REQUESTS.
   (a)   All employee complaints or requests shall be presented to the
department head for solution. The employee shall present his or her complaint
or request personally. In the event the complaint or request is not resolved at
this level it may be reduced to writing and submitted to the Director of Public
Service and Safety.
   (b)   The Director of Public Service and Safety shall investigate, or cause
an investigation to be conducted, to determine the facts of the case and then
shall take whatever action he or she deems necessary.
   (c)   Complaints and requests of employees other than those in the
Department of Public Service and Safety shall be handled in the same manner
with the exception that the appropriate City official shall make the final
disposition.
(Ord. 2003-26. Passed 5-5-03; Ord. 2006-31. Passed 7-17-06.)
260.23 PERSONAL REQUIREMENTS AND GENERAL REGULATIONS.
   (a)   Consideration of political or religious opinions as a test for
employment or promotion in any position of the City service shall not be
practiced. Membership in any organization shall not be required of City
employees.
   (b)   Since City employees are members of the Ohio Public Employees
Retirement System and Police and Fire Pension Fund, the rules pertaining to age
of retirement shall be in conformity with those established by the Ohio Revised
Code and legal interpretations thereof.
   (c)   The City of Wapakoneta is an Equal Opportunity Employer and as such
will comply with the rules and regulations established for that purpose.
   (d)   The Director of Public Service and Safety shall consult with the
department head and determine the educational requirements for appointment to
specific positions in the Department of Public Service and Safety.
   (e)   All rules and regulations of the City governing employees and
employment matters are decided on the assumption that all permanent employees
and, as nearly as possible, all other employees, are persons of good character,
skilled in their work and adaptable to the working conditions associated with
public utility and City operations.
   (f)   Full-time employees may not carry on concurrently with their City
employment any private business or undertaking, attention to which affects the
time or quality of their City work.
   (g)   No employee shall use or permit the use of any City equipment or
facilities under his or her control for any purpose other than official use,
except as may be designated and determined by the Director of Public Service
and Safety, when no equipment or facilities can be furnished from a private
source.
   (h)   It shall be grounds for dismissal for an employee to seek or receive
compensation or special favors from any source other than the City in
connection with the carrying out of official duties and responsibilities.
(Ord. 2003-26. Passed 5-5-03; Ord. 2006-31. Passed 7-17-06.)
260.24 DISCIPLINARY ACTION.
   (a)   An employee who is unsuitable for the duties assigned to him or her or
who violates any provision of this chapter may be terminated at the discretion
of the Director of Public Service and Safety.
   (b)   The Director may approve and adopt such additional rules, regulations
and policies as may be necessary for efficient discipline in the various
departments of the City.
(Ord. 2003-26. Passed 5-5-03; Ord. 2006-31. Passed 7-17-06.)
260.25 UNEMPLOYMENT PROVISIONS.
   The unemployment provisions passed by the General Assembly of the State
shall apply to all applicable employees of the City.
(Ord. 2003-26. Passed 5-5-03; Ord. 2006-31. Passed 7-17-06.)
260.26 PAY PERIOD.
   All employees shall be paid biweekly, on every other Friday. The pay period
shall be designated to begin at 12:01 a.m. Monday through to the following 12:
00 midnight Sunday in all departments except the Fire Department, which shall
be from 7:00 a.m. Sunday through to the following Sunday at 7:00 a.m.
(Ord. 2003-26. Passed 5-5-03; Ord. 2006-31. Passed 7-17-06.)
260.27 POSITION FUNDING.
   Various positions of City employment mandate responsibilities to different
departments and thus should be compensated in proportion to the responsibility
to each department. City Council will each year, in its appropriations, set the
proportionate pay for these positions as to payment responsibilities of each
City fund.
(Ord. 2003-26. Passed 5-5-03; Ord. 2006-31. Passed 7-17-06.)
260.28 REPRESENTATIVE BODY.
   (a)   The non-supervisory full-time employees of the City may establish a
representative body to consider the interests of the employees. This body shall
serve as an intermediary between the City Council, the administration and the
employees in matters of the employees' compensation program.
   (b)   The representative body shall be given the opportunity to comment on
changes in the City's compensation program prior to enactment and to provide
input in the formulation process.
(Ord. 2003-26. Passed 5-5-03; Ord. 2006-31. Passed 7-17-06.)
260.29 STANDARD WORK WEEK.
   The standard work week is forty hours for all hourly employees, except as
follows:
   (a)   The standard work period for employees of the Fire Department shall be
28 days, during which fire-fighters and captains shall be scheduled to work 212
hours per period.
   (b)   The standard work period for all part-time positions, as designated by
the Director of Public Service and Safety, is as required.
(Ord. 2003-26. Passed 5-5-03; Ord. 2006-31. Passed 7-17-06.)
260.30 ASSIGNMENT OF BARGAINING UNIT EMPLOYEES TO TEMPORARY SUPERVISORY
POSITIONS WITHIN UTILITY DEPARTMENTS; COMPENSATION.
   (a)   The Director of Public Service and Safety is hereby authorized to
establish and maintain a policy that addresses the temporary assignment of
bargaining unit employees to serve in the capacity of “department supervisor”
within the various utility departments.
   (b)   When approved, in writing, by the Director of Public Service and
Safety, the Payroll Clerk is authorized to incorporate a subsidy of two dollars
($2.00) per hour into the pay rate of bargaining unit employees assigned to
perform temporary supervisory duties, and said subsidy shall be a flat hourly
rate and shall not be compounded for overtime hours.
(Ord. 2003-26. Passed 5-5-03; Ord. 2006-31. Passed 7-17-06; Ord. 2024-54.
Passed 1-6-25.)

CHAPTER 274
Parks and Recreation Advisory Commission
274.01   Establishment.
274.02   Membership.
274.03   Terms.
274.04   Purpose.
274.05   Meetings.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Land appropriation for parks - see Ohio R.C. 715.21, 719.01
   Construction of centers - see Ohio R.C. 717.01
   Parks and playgrounds - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 755
   Recreation boards - see Ohio R.C. 755.14, 755.15
   Expenses of Recreation Board - see Ohio R.C. 755.18
   Park Commission - see ADM. Ch.
278
   Parks and recreational facilities - see S.U. & P.S. Ch.
1062
274.01 ESTABLISHMENT.
   The Parks and Recreation Advisory Commission of the City of Wapakoneta is
hereby created effective January 1, 2024.
(Ord. 2023-49. Passed 10-2-23.)
274.02 MEMBERSHIP.
   The Parks and Recreation Advisory Commission shall consist of five members.
Two voting members of the Committee shall be appointed by City Council. Two
members shall be appointed by the Mayor of Wapakoneta. One member shall be
designated by the Wapakoneta City Board of Education. The Recreation Director
and Director of Public Service and Safety shall serve as ex-officio non-voting
members. All members of the Parks and Recreation Advisory Commission shall be
electors of the City of Wapakoneta.
(Ord. 2023-49. Passed 10-2-23; Ord. 2024-37. Passed 8-19-24.)
274.03 TERMS.
   (a)   All regular members of the Parks and Recreation Advisory Commission
shall be appointed for four-year terms without limit.
   (b)   Ex-officio members of the Parks and Recreation Advisory Commission
shall include the Recreation Director and Director of Public Service and
Safety.
   (c)   Commission members shall elect their own Chairperson and Secretary to
serve as officers for one-year periods.
(Ord. 2023-49. Passed 10-2-23.)
274.04 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of the Parks and Recreation Advisory Commission shall be to:
   (a)   Promote the development of a comprehensive parks system in the City;
   (b)   Make recommendations to City Council and staff on matters pertaining
to the development and improvement of parks and recreational facilities owned
by the City of Wapakoneta. Final decisions regarding the use of City
appropriations for parks and recreational facilities and equipment shall be
made by City Council;
   (c)   Provide for citizen input on park matters;
   (d)   Guide planning efforts to ensure the development of a Parks and Open
Space Master Plan.
(Ord. 2023-49. Passed 10-2-23.)
274.05 MEETINGS.
   (a)   The Commission shall meet in January, March, May, July, September, and
November of each year at a time and location as determined by the Commission.
The Chair of the Commission, or a majority of voting members, may cancel any
regularly scheduled meeting or schedule additional meetings provided notice of
not less than twenty-four hours is provided to all members and the media.
   (b)   All meetings of the Commission are open to the public for attendance
and participation.
   (c)   A quorum shall consist of three regular members.
(Ord. 2023-49. Passed 10-2-23.)

276.01 ESTABLISHMENT; MEMBERSHIP; COMPENSATION.
   (a)   A Sewer Commission is hereby established in and for the City.
   (b)   The Commission shall consist of three members, namely the Chairperson
of the City Council Sewer Committee, the Director of Public Service and Safety
and the Superintendent of the Sewer Treatment Plant.
   (c)   The members of the Commission shall serve without pay.
(Ord. 74-18. Passed 4-17-74.)
276.02 ORGANIZATION; PROCEDURES.
   The Sewer Commission shall organize itself and establish procedures for the
conduct of its business and other matters that may legally come before it.
(Ord. 74-18. Passed 4-17-74.)
276.03 FUNCTIONS.
   The Sewer Commission shall meet and make recommendations to the City Council
as to when and where lift stations may be permitted. The Commission shall
establish guidelines as to what information is required of an applicant in
determining the feasibility of allowing a lift station to be installed in the
sewer system of the City.
(Ord. 74-18. Passed 4-17-74.)
CHAPTER 278
Park Commission
278.01   Establishment; membership.
278.02   Terms of office.
278.03   Vacancies.
278.04   Officers.
278.05   Duties of officers.
278.06   Duties of the Commission.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Land appropriation for parks - see Ohio R.C. 715.21, 719.01
   Council may donate money and supplies to parks - see Ohio R.C. 715.211
   Municipality may provide land for parks - see Ohio R.C. 717.01
   Director of Public Service and Safety to manage parks - see Ohio R.C. 735.02
   Parks and playgrounds - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 755
   Parks and Recreation Advisory Commission - see ADM. Ch.
274
   Parks and recreational facilities - see S.U. & P.S. Ch.
1062
278.01 ESTABLISHMENT; MEMBERSHIP.
   (a)   A Park Commission is hereby established in and for the City.
   (b)   The Park Commission shall consist of seven City electors who shall
serve without remuneration.
   (c)   The members of the Commission shall be appointed by the Mayor and be
approved by a majority of the elected Council members of the City.
(Ord. 74-63. Passed 11-6-74.)
278.02 TERMS OF OFFICE.
   The term of office for Park Commission members shall be five years. The
first and second members appointed shall serve for a period of three years; the
fifth and sixth members appointed shall serve for four years; the seventh
member for five years; thereafter appointments to fill vacancies created by
completion of tenure shall be for a period of five years.
(Ord. 74-63. Passed 11-6-74.)
278.03 VACANCIES.
   Vacancies in the Park Commission other than those provided for in Section
278.02, shall be filled by appointment of the Mayor and approved by a majority
of the elected Council members for the unexpired term to which appointment was
made.
(Ord. 74-63. Passed 11-6-74.)
278.04 OFFICERS.
   The Park Commission shall organize itself within thirty days after approval
by the Council, designating a Chairperson, Vice-Chairperson and Secretary to
serve for a period of one year, plus the fraction thereof of the first year,
with an organizational meeting to be held each year thereafter in January. The
Commission shall establish a regular time and place for monthly meetings and
may call special meetings at the written request of a majority of its members,
or by a majority vote in a regular meeting.
(Ord. 74-63. Passed 11-6-74.)
278.05 DUTIES OF OFFICERS.
   (a)   Chairperson. He or she shall preside over meetings and conduct the
business of the Commission.
   (b)   Vice-Chairperson. He or she shall preside during the absence or
inability of the Chairperson to serve and shall perform other duties as may be
assigned.
   (c)   Secretary. He or she shall keep a record of the proceedings of all
meetings and have them available upon request.
(Ord. 74-63. Passed 11-6-74.)
278.06 DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION.
   The Park Commission shall meet with citizens and citizens' groups of the
City for the purpose of developing a plan for the creation of a recreation area
on land owned by the City and shall present the plan or plans and/or
recommendations to the City Council for approval and disposition.
(Ord. 74-63. Passed 11-6-74.)
CHAPTER 280
Tree Commission
280.01   Purpose and objectives; establishment; membership; compensation.
280.02   Terms of office.
280.03   Powers and duties.
280.04   Officers; rules and regulations; journal; quorum.
280.05   Review of conduct, acts and decisions by City Council.
280.06   Interference with Commission prohibited.
280.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Shade trees and shrubbery - see Ohio R.C. 715.20
   Tree assessments - see Ohio R.C. 727.011
   Injuring vines, bushes, trees or crops - see GEN. OFF.
642.06
   Weeds and pass - see GEN. OFF.
660.14
   Trees generally - see S.U. & P.S. Ch.
1028
280.01 PURPOSE AND OBJECTIVES; ESTABLISHMENT; MEMBERSHIP; COMPENSATION.
   (a)   Purpose Statement and Objectives.
      (1)   It is the purpose of this chapter to promote and protect the public
health, safety and general welfare by providing for the regulation of the
planting, maintenance and removal of trees, shrubs and other plants within the
City.
      (2)   To assist residents in planting and the care of trees on private
property.
      (3)   To follow State forestry safety and care of all trees within the
City corporation limits.
      (4)   Distribute current information about the urban forest care to the
City residents.
      (5)   Establish an Arbor Day observation annually.
      (6)   Establish and maintain a tree inventory for the City of Wapakoneta.
      (7)   Follow the planting and species planting guidelines established by
the State Urban Forestry.
      (8)   Hold regularly scheduled meetings.
   (b)   There is hereby established a Tree Commission in and for the City,
which Commission shall consist of seven members.
   (c)   One member shall be appointed by City Council from the members of the
City Council's Streets and Alleys Committee. One member shall be Superintendent
of the Electric Department. One member shall be the Mayor of the City of
Wapakoneta. One member shall be an employee from the City Engineering
Department appointed by the Mayor. The remaining three members, whom shall be
citizens and residents of the City of Wapakoneta, shall be appointed by the
Mayor with the approval of the Council. The Tree Commission may appoint
consultants to the Tree Commission at their discretion. Any such consultant
shall have no voting authority and shall serve at the discretion of the Tree
Commission.
   (d)   Members of the Commission shall serve without compensation.
(Ord. 83-22. Passed 8-17-83; Ord. 2014-37. Passed 12-1-14.)
280.02 TERMS OF OFFICE.
   (a)   The term of the persons to be appointed by the Mayor shall be three
years. The member from the Streets and Alleys Committee of City Council shall
be appointed annually. The term of the Mayor shall be consistent with the
elected term for the Mayor.
   (b)   In the event that a vacancy shall occur during the term of any member
appointed by the Mayor, his or her successor shall be appointed by the Mayor
for the unexpired portion of the term. In the event that a vacancy shall occur
during the term of the member appointed by the City Council, his or her
successor shall be appointed by the City Council for the unexpired portion of
the term.
(Ord. 83-22. Passed 8-17-83; Ord. 2014-37. Passed 12-1-14.)
280.03 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   (a)   It shall be the responsibility of the Tree Commission to study,
investigate, counsel, develop or update annually, and administer, a written
plan for the care, preservation, pruning, planting, replanting, removal or
disposition of trees and shrubs in parks, along streets and in other public
areas.
   (b)   The plan will be presented annually to the City Council, and upon its
acceptance and approval shall constitute the Official Comprehensive Tree Plan
for the City.
   (c)   The Commission, when requested by the City Council, shall consider,
investigate, make findings, report and recommend upon any special matter or
question coming within the scope of its work.
   (d)   In the performance of its duties, the Tree Commission shall consider
and remain consistent with the provisions of Chapter 1028 of the Codified
Ordinances of the City of Wapakoneta, as enacted or as may be amended.
(Ord. 83-22. Passed 8-17-83; Ord. 2014-37. Passed 12-1-14.)
280.04 OFFICERS; RULES AND REGULATIONS; JOURNAL; QUORUM.
   (a)   The Tree Commission shall choose its own officers, make its own rules
and regulations and keep a journal of its proceedings.
   (b)   A majority of the members shall be a quorum for the transaction of
business.
(Ord. 83-22. Passed 8-17-83.)
280.05 REVIEW OF CONDUCT, ACTS AND DECISIONS BY CITY COUNCIL.
   The City Council shall have the right to review the conduct, acts and
decisions of the Tree Commission. Any person may appeal from any ruling or
order of the Tree Commission to the City Council, which may hear the matter and
make a final decision.
(Ord. 83-22. Passed 8-17-83; Ord. 84-14. Passed 3-7-84.)
280.06 INTERFERENCE WITH COMMISSION PROHIBITED.
   No person shall prevent, delay or interfere with the Tree Commission, or any
of its agents, while they are engaging in and about the planting, cultivation,
mulching, pruning, spraying or removing of any street trees, or trees on
private grounds, as authorized in this chapter.
(Ord. 83-22. Passed 8-17-83.)
280.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for
each offense.
