   (b)   The following exemption shall apply regarding the fee set forth in
subsection (a) hereof, for opening a new or newly improved street:
      (1)   Connections to natural gas, water or sewer mains to serve new
buildings shall be exempt from the payment schedule listed above. The providing
for service to these vacant parcels shall be planned for prior to a street
reconstruction or repaving project and where practical shall be installed in
advance so as to prevent opening the new street during the ten year period
following construction.
(Ord. 2019-05. Passed 2-18-19.)
1024.07 RIGHT TO WAIVE A STREET OPENING PERMIT PAYMENT.
   The City shall have the right to waive the street opening permit payment in
the case of an opening required as a result of a natural disaster such as flood
or earthquake, but shall not be limited to these disasters listed. The Director
of Public Service and Safety shall also have the authority to waive payments as
required under the payment schedule in Section 1024.06 if it is determined that
the need to open a street that has been resurfaced or reconstructed in the ten-
year period shown on the schedule is due to circumstances beyond the control of
the utility involved or is the result of unusual conditions that could not have
been foreseen during street resurfacing or reconstruction.
(Ord. 2019-05. Passed 2-18-19.)
1024.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than one hundred fifty dollars
($150.00) for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed each
day during or on which a violation occurs or continues.
(Ord. 2019-05. Passed 2-18-19.)
CHAPTER 1026
Drainage
1026.01   Installation of facilities; permit required.
1026.02   Plans, specifications and profiles.
1026.03   City ownership of sewers; approval of workmanship; maintenance.
1026.04   Maintenance and repair after one year.
1026.05   Issuance of permit.
1026.06   Nonliability of City.
1026.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Municipal sewer districts - see Ohio R.C. 727.44 et seq.
   Repair or reconstruction of ditches - see Ohio R.C. 729.46
   Notice to fill lots, remove putrid substances - see GEN. OFF.
660.11
   Sewers generally - see S.U. & P.S. Ch.
1040
   Storm drainage generally - see S.U. & P.S. Ch.
1043
   Drainage in subdivisions - see P. & Z.
1244.04(c)(3),
1248.05
   Flood damage prevention - see B. & H. Ch.
1476
1026.01 INSTALLATION OF FACILITIES; PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person shall install, construct or maintain a sewer, drain or tile,
through, in or under the public streets or alleys, whether or not said streets
or alleys have been open to public use, for the drainage or disposal of sewage,
industrial waste or storm water, without first obtaining a permit therefor from
the Director of Public Service and Safety.
(1978 Code § 94.10)
1026.02 PLANS, SPECIFICATIONS AND PROFILES.
   (a)   No person shall be granted a permit to install, construct or maintain
a sewer, drain or tile through, in or under the public streets or alleys
whether or not the streets or alleys have been open to public use, for the
purpose of draining or disposing of sewage, industrial waste or storm water,
until the person has presented his or her plans, specifications and profiles of
the proposed work to the Director of Public Service and Safety and has had the
same approved by the Director.
   (b)   The Director of Public Service and Safety shall, before approving the
plans, specifications and profiles, consider the relation of the proposed
installation or construction to the plan of sewerage existing in the area where
the sewer, drain or tile, is to be installed, constructed or maintained. He or
she shall also consider the adequacy of the proposed sewer, drain or tile, with
reference to present and future expected flows, and the availability of the
sewer to the properties abutting on the street or alley wherein the sewer is to
be installed, constructed or maintained.
(1978 Code § 94.11)
1026.03 CITY OWNERSHIP OF SEWERS; APPROVAL OF WORKMANSHIP; MAINTENANCE.
   No person shall be granted a permit to install, construct or maintain a
sewer, drain or tile through, in or under the public streets or alley whether
or not the streets or alleys are open to public use, for the purpose of
drainage or disposal of sewage, industrial waste or storm water, until the
person has agreed, in writing, prior to the granting of a permit, that the
sewer, drain or tile shall become the complete and sole property of the City
upon completion of the installation or construction of the sewer. Completion
must be to the satisfaction of the Director of Public Service and Safety. The
person shall be responsible for maintenance and repair of the sewer, drain or
tile for a one-year period from the date of completion.
(1978 Code § 94.12)
1026.04 MAINTENANCE AND REPAIR AFTER ONE YEAR.
   The Director of Public Service and Safety is hereby authorized to enter into
contracts with applicants for permits to install, construct or maintain a
sewer, drain or tile through, in or under the public streets or alleys and to
obligate the City, by such contracts, to maintain and repair said sewers,
drains or tiles after the one-year maintenance period following completion of
same.
(1978 Code § 94.13)
1026.05 ISSUANCE OF PERMIT.
   The Director of Public Service and Safety shall issue a permit to any person
complying with the provisions of this chapter for the construction, maintenance
or installation of a sewer, drain or tile through, in or under the public
streets or alleys.
(1978 Code § 94.14)
1026.06 NONLIABILITY OF CITY.
   The City shall not be liable, by reason of the issuance of a permit under
this chapter, for the costs of construction or installation of a sewer, drain
or tile, nor shall the City be liable for any defective construction of the
same during the one-year period following completion of the installation or
construction to the satisfaction of the Director of Public Service and Safety.
(1978 Code § 94.15)
1026.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for
each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during or
on which a violation occurs or continues.
CHAPTER 1028
Trees
1028.01   Definitions.
1028.02   Arborists; license required; fee; insurance.
1028.03   Street tree species authorized to be planted.

1028.07   Distance from utility lines.
1028.08   Public tree care.

visibility.
1028.11   Removal of dead or diseased trees from private property.
1028.12   Dangerous trees.
1028.13   Removal of stumps.
1028.14   Trees in new subdivisions.

   CROSS REFERENCES
   Power to regulate shade trees and shrubbery - see Ohio R.C. 715.20
   Assessments for tree planting or maintenance - see Ohio R.C. 727.011
   Dutch elm disease - see Ohio R.C. 927.39 to 927.42
   Tree Commission - see ADM. Ch.
280
   Injuring vines, bushes, trees or crops - see GEN. OFF.
642.06
   Weeds and grass - see GEN. OFF.
660.14
1028.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply unless
the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   (a)   "Park trees" means trees, shrubs, bushes and all other woody
vegetation in public parks having individual names, and in all areas owned by
the City, or to which the public has free access as it has to a park.
   (b)   "Street trees" means trees, shrubs, bushes and all other woody
vegetation on land lying between property lines on either side of all streets
or other public ways within the City.
   (c)   "Topping" means the severe cutting back of limbs to stubs larger than
three inches in diameter within the tree's crown, to such a degree so as to
remove the normal canopy and disfigure the tree.
(Ord. 83-22. Passed 8-17-83.)
1028.02 ARBORISTS; LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE; INSURANCE.
   (a)   No person shall engage in the business or occupation of pruning,
treating or removing street trees or park trees within the City, or to prune,
treat or remove trees within the City, in return for any compensation,
consideration or remuneration, without first applying for and procuring a
license therefor.
   (b)   The license fee shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00) annually in
advance, provided, however, that no license shall be required of any City
employee, agent or contractor doing such work in the pursuit of his or her
public service endeavors.
   (c)   Before any license shall be issued, each applicant shall first file
evidence of possession of worker's compensation insurance and of liability
insurance in the minimum amounts of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000) for
bodily injury and one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000) for property damage,
indemnifying the City or any person injured or damaged as a result of the
pursuit of such endeavors as are herein described.
(Ord. 83-22. Passed 8-17-83; Ord. 84-14. Passed 3-7-84.)
1028.03 STREET TREE SPECIES AUTHORIZED TO BE PLANTED.
   Pursuant to Section
280.03(a) of the Administration Code, the Tree Commission annually reviews,
updates and prepares the official list of street tree species authorized to be
planted in the City. At least one copy of said official list is on file with
the Clerk of Council for inspection by the public. In addition, the Clerk of
Council shall keep copies of such official list available for distribution to
the public, at cost. No species other than those listed may be planted as
street trees without written permission of the Tree Commission. The official
list identifies trees by three categories, as follows:
   (a)   Large Trees. Such trees reach a height of forty-five feet or more at
maturity. They are suitable for planting in tree lawns of eight feet or more
where no overhead utility lines are present.
   (b)   Medium Trees. Such trees reach a height of thirty to forty-five feet
at maturity. They are suitable for planting in tree lawns of six to eight feet
where no overhead utility lines are present.
   (c)   Small Trees. Such trees reach a height of ten to thirty feet at
maturity. They are suitable for planting in tree lawns of four to six feet, and
in wider tree lawns where overhead utility lines are present.
1028.04 SPACING.
   The spacing of street trees will be in accordance with the three species
size classes referred to in Section
1028.04 and, except in special plantings designed or approved by the Tree
Commission, no trees may be planted closer together than the following:
   (a)   Small trees - thirty feet;
   (b)   Medium trees - forty feet;
   (c)   Large trees - fifty feet.
(Ord. 83-22. Passed 8-17-83.)
1028.05 DISTANCE FROM CURBS AND SIDEWALKS.
   The distance that trees may be planted from curbs or curblines and sidewalks
will be in accordance with the three species size classes referred in Section
1028.04, and no trees may be planted closer to any curb or sidewalk than the
following:
   (a)   Small trees - two feet;
   (b)   Medium trees - three feet;
   (c)   Large trees - four feet.
(Ord. 83-22. Passed 8-17-83.)
1028.06 DISTANCE FROM STREET CORNERS AND FIREPLUGS.
   (a)   No street tree shall be planted closer than thirty-five feet from any
street corner, measured from the point of the nearest intersecting curbs or
curblines.
   (b)   No street tree shall be planted closer than ten feet from any
fireplug.
(Ord. 83-22. Passed 8-17-83; Ord. 2024-33. Passed 8-19-24.)
1028.07 DISTANCE FROM UTILITY LINES.
   No street tree, other than those species referred to as "small trees" in
Section
1028.04, may be planted under or within ten lateral feet of any overhead
utility wire, or over or within five lateral feet of any underground water
line, sewer line, distribution line or other utility.
(Ord. 83-22. Passed 8-17-83.)
1028.08 PUBLIC TREE CARE.
   (a)   The City shall have the right to plant, prune, maintain and remove
trees, plants and shrubs within the lines of all streets, alleys, avenues,
lanes, squares and public grounds, as may be necessary to insure public safety
or to preserve or enhance the symmetry and beauty of such public grounds.
   (b)   The Tree Commission may remove or cause or order to be removed any
tree or part thereof which is in an unsafe condition, or which, by reason of
its nature, is injurious to sewers, electric power lines, gas lines, water
lines or other public improvements, or which is infected with any injurious
fungus, insect or other pest.
   (c)   This section does not prohibit the planting of street trees by
adjacent property owners, providing that the selection and location of the
trees is in accordance with Sections
1028.03 through
1028.07.
(Ord. 83-22. Passed 8-17-83.)
1028.09 TOPPING.
   (a)   No person or City department shall top any street tree, park tree or
other tree on public property, except, however, that a person who holds a grant
of right of way by easement or otherwise, or a City department, may prune or
top trees which might interfere with or endanger the safe and efficient
operation of a service provided by that person or City department.
   (b)   Trees severely damaged by storms or other causes, or certain trees
under utility wires or other obstructions, where other pruning practices are
impractical, may be exempted from this section at the determination of the Tree
Commission.
(Ord. 83-22. Passed 8-17-83.)
1028.10 PRUNING; AND REMOVAL; OBSTRUCTION OF STREET LIGHTS AND TRAFFIC
VISIBILITY.
   (a)   Every owner of any tree overhanging any street or right of way within
the City shall prune the branches so that the branches shall not obstruct the
light from any street lamp or obstruct the view of any street intersection, and
so that there shall be a clear space of eight feet above the surface of the
sidewalk and a clear space of twelve feet above that portion of a street
outside the curb, or that portion of a street or right of way subject to
vehicular traffic.
   (b)   The owners shall remove all dead, diseased or dangerous trees, or
broken or decayed limbs which constitute a menace to the safety of the public.
   (c)   The City shall have the right to prune any tree or shrub on private
property when it interferes with the proper spread of light along the street
from a street light or interferes with visibility of any traffic control device
or sign.
(Ord. 83-22. Passed 8-17-83.)
1028.11 REMOVAL OF DEAD OR DISEASED TREES FROM PRIVATE PROPERTY.
   (a)   The City shall have the right to cause the removal of any dead or
diseased trees on private property within the City, when those trees constitute
a hazard to life and property or harbor insects or disease which constitutes a
potential threat to other trees within the City.
   (b)   The Tree Commission will notify in writing the owners of such trees.
   (c)   Removal shall be done by the owners at their own expense within sixty
days after the date of service of notice.
   (d)   In the event of failure of the owners to comply with such provisions,
the City shall have the authority to remove the trees and charge the cost of
removal on the owner's property tax notice.
(Ord. 83-22. Passed 8-17-83.)
1028.12 DANGEROUS TREES.
   No owner or occupant of any lot or parcel of land on which there exists a
tree or bush in such condition as to cause imminent danger to pedestrians using
the sidewalks, or vehicles and persons using the streets and alleys, shall
permit such tree or bush to remain in a dangerous condition. The owner or
occupant shall cause the dangerous tree or bush to be removed, or cause the
same to be fixed or repaired.
(1978 Code § 94.41)
1028.13 REMOVAL OF STUMPS.
   All stumps of street and park trees shall be removed below the surface of
the ground to facilitate landscaping.
(Ord. 83-22. Passed 8-17-83.)
1028.14 TREES IN NEW SUBDIVISIONS.
   The Tree Commission shall approve the tree plan for any new subdivisions.
(Ord. 83-22. Passed 8-17-83.)
1028.15 ABUSE OR MUTILATION.
   No person shall abuse, destroy or mutilate any tree, shrub or plant in a
public tree lawn or any other public place, or attach or place any rope or wire
(other than one used to support a young or broken tree), sign, poster, handbill
or other thing to or on any tree growing in a public place, or allow any
gaseous, liquid or solid substance which is harmful to the trees to come in
contact with their roots or leaves.
(Ord. 83-22. Passed 8-17-83.)
1028.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). In
addition, the person shall replace the tree with a size and species recommended
by the Tree Commission. Each tree affected by a violation of this chapter shall
constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 83-22. Passed 8-17-83.)

CHAPTER 1038
Utilities-General Provisions
1038.01   Connections to utilities; approval required.
1038.01 CONNECTIONS TO UTILITIES; APPROVAL REQUIRED.
   (a)   No property outside the corporate limits of the City may be connected
to, or receive service from, any of the utilities listed under this Title Four
without prior approval from City Council.
      (1)   The decision to allow properties outside the corporate limits to
connect to, or receive service from, any of the utilities listed under this
Title Four will be on a strictly case-by-case basis with each case being
evaluated for its impact on the existing systems.
   (b)   The requirements of this Title Four and all other applicable and
legally binding local ordinances and codifications shall be followed when a
property has been authorized by the City in order to connect to, or receive
service from, any of the utilities listed under this Title Four.
   (c)   Billing adjustments shall be made as follows:
      (1)   If the customer has been overcharged for utility services because
of a malfunction in the metering system or a billing error, overcharges will be
refunded to the customer for the entire period of inaccurate billing, if that
period is identifiable by the municipality. If the period of inaccurate billing
is not identifiable, overcharges will be calculated based on a time period that
is the shortest of the time elapsed since the customer's service began, the
date of installation of the faulty meter or implementation of the error
resulting in the overcharge (if applicable), or 365 days.
      (2)   If a customer has been undercharged for utility services because of
a malfunction in the metering system or a billing error, undercharges will be
billed to the customer, and the customer shall pay the charges for the entire
period of inaccurate billing, if that period is identifiable by the
municipality. If the period of inaccurate billing is not identifiable,
undercharges will be calculated based on a time period that is shortest of the
time elapsed since the customer's service began, that date of installation of
the faulty meter or implementation of the error resulting in the undercharge
(if applicable), or 365 days. Undercharges billed to customers shall in no
event exceed a period of 365 days. Customers shall have the option to pay the
amount undercharged in equal payments spread over the same number of months as
the charges were accumulated.
      (3)   This section does not serve as a limitation to billing for
undercharges which are the result of tampering with utility equipment or theft
of utility services, or where a physical act of a customer or its agent causes
inaccurate or no recording of the meter reading, or inaccurate or no
measurements rendered.
(Ord. 2015-41. Passed 11-2-15; Ord. 2017-25. Passed 8-7-17; Ord. 2019-35R.
Passed 8-5-19.)
